div.p: AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR T. BECKET, IN THE STRAND. 1774.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: THE Author of the following performance cannot commit it to the preſs, without acknowledging the deepeſt ſenſe of gratitude, for the uncommon marks of approbation with which he has been honoured by the Public.

Tho' he has choſen a title us'd by MOLIERE, he has neither borrowed a ſingle circumſtance from that great poet, nor to the beſt of his recollection from any other writer.—His chief ſtudy has been to ſteer between the extremes of ſentimental gloom, and the exceſſes of unintereſting levity; he has ſome laugh, yet he hopes he has alſo ſome leſſon; and faſhionable as it has been lately for the wits,
even with his friend Mr. Garrick at their head, to ridicule the Comic Muſe, when a little grave, he muſt think that ſhe degenerates into farce, where the grand buſineſs of inſtruction is neglected, and conſider it as a hereſy in criticiſm, to ſay that one of the moſt arduous taſks within the reach of literature, ſhou'd, when executed; be wholly without utility.

The Author having been preſumptuous enough to aſſert, that he has not purloin'd a ſingle ſprig of bays from the brow of any other writer, he may, perhaps, be aſk'd, if there are not ſeveral plays in the Engliſh language, which, before his, produced Generals, Lawyers, Iriſhmen, Duels, Maſquerades, and Miſtakes? He anſwers, yes; and confeſſes moreover, that all the Comedies before his, were compos'd not only of men and women, but that before his, the great buſineſs of comedy conſiſted in making difficulties for the purpoſe of removing them; in diſtreſſing poor young lovers; and in rendering a happy marriage the object of every cataſtrophe.

Yet tho' the Author of the School for Wives, pleads guilty to all theſe charges, ſtill, in extenuation of his offence, he begs leave to obſerve, that having
only men and women to introduce upon the ſtage, he was oblig'd to compoſe his Dramatis Perſonae of mere fleſh and blood; if, however, he has thrown this fleſh and this blood, into new ſituations; if he has given a new fable, and plac'd his characters in a point of light hitherto unexhibited:—he flat.ters himſelf that he may call his play, a new play, and tho' it did not exiſt before the creation of the world, like the famous Welch pedigree, that he may have ſome ſmall pretenſions to originality.

Two things beſides the general moral inculcated thro' his piece, the Author has attempted; the firſt, to reſcue the law, as a profeſſion, from ridicule or obliquy; and the ſecond, to remove the imputation of a barbarous ferocity, which dramatic writers, even meaning to compliment the Iriſh nation, have connected with their Idea of that gallant people:—The law, like every other profeſſion, may have members who occaſionally diſgrace it; but to the glory of the Britiſh name, it is well know that in the worſt of times, it has produced numbers whoſe virtues reflected honour upon human nature; many of the nobleſt privileges the conſtitution has to boaſt of, were derived from the integrity, or the wiſdom of lawyers:
Yet the ſtage has hitherto caſt an indiſcriminate ſtigma upon the whole body, and laboured to make that profeſſion either odious or contemptible in the theatre, which, if the laws are indeed dear to good Engliſhmen, can never be too much reſpected in this kingdom. There is ſcarcely a play in which a lawyer is introduced, that is not a libel upon the long robe; and ſo ignorant have many dramatic writers been, that they have made no diſtinction whatever, between the characters of the firſt Barriſters in Weſtminſter-Hall, and the meaneſt ſolicitors at the Old Bailey.

With reſpect to the gentlemen of Ireland, where even an abſolue attempt is manifeſted, to place them in a favourable point of view, they are drawn with a brutal promptitude to quarrel, which is a diſgrace to the well known humanity of their country.—The gentlemen of Ireland have doubtleſs a quick ſenſe of honour, and, like the gentlemen of England, as well as like the gentlemen of every other high-ſpirited nation, are perhaps unhappily too ready to draw the ſword, where they conceive themſelves injured—But to make them proud of a barbarous propenſity to Duelling; to make them actually delight in the effuſion of blood, is to faſten a very unjuſt reproach upon their general character, and to render
them univerſally obnoxious to ſociety. The author of the School for Wives therefore, has given a different picture of Iriſh manners, though in humble life, and flatters himſelf that thoſe who are really acquainted with the original, will acknowlege it to be at leaſt a tolerable reſemblance.

It would be ungrateful in the higheſt degree to cloſe this preface, without acknowleging the very great obligations which the author has to Mr. Garrick. Every attention, which either as a manager, or as a man, he could give to the intereſt of the following play, he has beſtowed with the moſt generous alacrity; but univerſally admired as he is at preſent, his intrinſic value will not be known, till his loſs is deplored; and the public have great reaſon to wiſh, that this may be a very diſtant event in the annals of the theatre. The Epilogue ſufficiently marks the maſterly hand from which it originated; ſo does the comic commencement of the Prologue, and the elegant writer of the graver part, is a character of diſtinguiſhed eminence in the literary republic.

It has been remarked with great juſtice, that few new pieces were ever better performed than The School for Wives. Mr. King, that highly-deſerving
favourite of the town, was every thing the author could poſſibly wiſh in General Savage. Mr. Reddiſh acquired a very conſiderable ſhare of merited reputation in Belville. Mr. Moody is unequalled in his Iriſhmen. Mr. Palmer, from his manner of ſupporting Leeſon, was entitled to a much better part: And Mr. Weſton in Torington was admirable. Miſs Younge, in Mrs. Belville, extorted applauſe from the coldeſt auditor. Her tenderneſs—her force—her pathos, were the true effuſions of genius, and proved that ſhe has no ſuperior where the feelings are to be intereſted. With reſpect to Mrs. Abington, enough can never be ſaid. The elegance, the vivacity, the critical nicety with which ſhe went through Miſs Walſingham, is only to be gueſſed at, by thoſe who are familiar with the performance of that exquiſite actreſs. Her Epilogue was delivered with an animation not to be conceived, and manifeſted the ſtrict propriety, with which ſhe is called the firſt prieſteſs of the Comic Muſe in this country.

THE SCHOOL FOR WIVES, BEING A COMEDY IN WHICH THE LADIES ARE PARTICULARLY INTERESTED, IT SHOULD BE ADDRESS'D TO THE FIRST ORNAMENT OF THE SEX; AND IS THEREFORE INSCRIBED WITH THE HIGHEST ADMIRATION AND THE MOST PROFOUND REVERENCE, TO HER MAJESTY; NOT BECAUSE SHE IS THE GREATEST OF QUEENS, BUT BECAUSE IN THE MILDER, AND MORE ENDEARING RELATIONS OF LIFE, SHE IS THE BRIGHTEST PATTERN OF ALL THE FEMALE VIRTUES.

sp.l: NO coward he, who in this critick age,
Dares ſet his foot upon the dang'rous ſtage;
Theſe boards, like Ice, your footing will betray,

l.hi: Who can tread ſure upon a ſlipp'ry way?

sp.l: Yet ſome thro' five acts, ſlide with wond'rous ſkill,
Skim ſwift along, turn, ſtop, or wind at will!
Some tumble, and get up; ſome riſe no more;
While cruel criticks watch them on the ſhore,
And at each ſtumble make a helliſh roar!
A wiſe Philoſopher, hath truly noted,
(His name I have forgot, tho' often quoted,)
That fine-ſpun ſpirits from the ſlighteſt cauſe,
Draw to themſelves affliction, or applauſe:
So fares it with our Bard.—Laſt week he meets
Some hawkers, roaring up and down the ſtreets,
Lives, characters, behaviour, parentage,
Of ſome who lately left the mortal ſtage!
His ears ſo caught the ſound, and work'd his mind,
He thought his own name floated in the wind;
As thus—"Here is a faithful, true relation,
"Of the birth, parentage, and education,
"Laſt dying ſpeech, confeſſion, character,
"Of the unhappy malefacterer,
"And comick poet, Thomas Addle Brain!
"Who ſuffer'd Monday laſt at Drury Lane;
"All for the price of half-penny a piece;"
Still in his ears theſe horrid ſounds encreaſe!
Try'd and condemn'd, half executed too;
There ſtands the culprit; 'till repriev'd by you.

sp.speaker: Miſs YOUNGE.
sp.l: Pray give me leave—I've ſomething now to ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. KING.
sp.l: Is't at the School for Wives, you're taught this way?
The School for Huſbands teaches to obey.

lg.l: It is a ſhame, good Sirs, that brother King,
To joke and laughter, ſhould turn every thing.
Our frighted poet would have no denial,
But, begs me to ſay ſomething on his trial:
The School for Wives, as it to us belongs,
Should for our uſe be guarded with our tongues.
Ladies, prepare, arm well your brows and eyes,
From thoſe your thunder, theſe your light'ning flies.
Should ſtorms be riſing in the Pit—look down,
And ſtill the waves thus, fair ones, with a frown:
Or ſhould the Galleries for war declare;
Look up—your eyes will carry twice as far.
The concluſion of the Prologue from this line is by another hand.Our Bard, to noble triumphs points your way,
Bids you in moral principles be gay;
Something he'd alter in your education,
Something which hurting you, would hurt a nation:
Ingenuous natures wiſh you to reclaim?
By ſmiling virtue you'll inſure your aim:
That gilds with bliſs the matrimonial hours,
And blends her laurels with the ſweeteſt flowers.
Ye married fair! deign to attend our ſchool,
And without uſurpation learn to rule:
Soon will he ceaſe mean objects to purſue,
In conſcience wretched till he lives to you;
Your charms will reformation's pain beguile,
And vice receive a ſtab from every ſmile.

sp.l: CAN it be thought, ye wives! this ſcribbling fool,
Will draw you here, by calling you to School?
Does not he know, poor ſoul! to be directed,
Is what you hate, and more to be corrected!
Long have theſe walls to public fame been known,
An ancient College to inſtruct the town!
We've Schools for Rakes, for Fathers, Lovers, Wives,
For naughty girls and boys, to mend their lives:
Where ſome to yawn, ſome round about to look,
Some to be ſeen, few come to mind their book:
Some with high wit and humour hither run,
To ſweat the maſters—and they call it fun.
Some modiſh ſparks, true ſtoicks, and high bred,
Come, but ne'er know what's done, or ſung, or ſaid;
Should the whole herd of criticks round them roar,
And with one voice cry out, encore! encore!
Or louder yet, off, off; no more! no more!
Should Pit, Box, Gall'ry with convulſions ſhake,
Still are they half aſleep, nor t'other half awake;
O, ladies fair! are theſe fit men to wed?
Such huſbands, half, had better be quite dead.
But, to return,—vain men, throughout the nation,
Boaſt, they alone, have College education:
Are not we qualify'd to take degrees?
We've caps, and gowns, nay bands too, if you pleaſe,
Cornelly's, and Almack's, our Univerſities!
Young female ſtudents riſe, if girls of parts,
From under graduates,—miſtreſſes of arts!
The baſhful ſpinſters, turn important ſpouſes,
Strive to be maſters, and the heads of houſes!
Will any of you here, bleſt with a wife,
Diſpute the fact,—you dare not for your life.
Pray tell me truly, criticks, and be free,
Do you this night prefer the Wife to me?
Shall Mrs. Belville give the Play a name?
What are her merits? a cold, ſmiling dame,
While I, a ſalamander, liv'd in flame!
Preſs'd by three lovers!—'twas indeed provoking!
Ladies, upon my word, it was no joking.
Can you from mortal woman more require,
Than ſave her fingers, and yet play with fire?
The riſks I run, the partial hard upbraids;
Wives won't be taught,—be it the School for Maids.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Enter Captain SAVAGE, and Miſs WALSINGHAM.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: HA! ha! ha! Well, Miſs Walſingham, this fury is going; what a noble peal ſhe has rung in Belville's ears!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Did ſhe ſee you, Captain Savage?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: No, I took care of that; for tho' ſhe is'n't married to my father, ſhe has ten times the influence of a wife, and might injure me not a little with him, if I didn't ſupport her ſide of the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: It was a pleaſant conceit of Mr. Belville, to inſinuate the poor woman was diſordered in her ſenſes!—

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And did you obſerve how the termagant's violence of temper, ſupported the probability of the charge?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe became almoſt frantic in reality, when ſhe found herſelf treated like a madwoman.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Belville's affected ſurpriſe too, was admirable!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Yes, the hypocritical compoſure of his countenance, and his counterfeit pity for the poor woman, were intolerable!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: While that amiable creature, his wife, implicitly believed every ſyllable he ſaid—

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: And felt nothing but pity for the accuſer, inſtead of paying the leaſt regard to the accuſation. But pray, is it really under a pretence of getting the girl upon the ſtage, that Belville has taken away Mrs. Tempeſt's neice from the people ſhe boarded with?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: It is: Belville, ever on the look out for freſh objects, met her in thoſe primitive regions of purity, the Green-Boxes; where, diſcovering that ſhe was paſſionately deſirous of becoming an actreſs, he improved his acquaintance with her, in the fictitious character of an Iriſh manager, and ſhe eloped laſt night, to be, as ſhe imagines, the heroine of a Dublin theatre.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: So, then, as he has kept his real name artfully conceal'd, Mrs. Tempeſt can at moſt but ſuſpect him of Miſs Leeſon's ſeduction.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Of no more; and this, only, from the deſcription of the people who ſaw him in company with her at the play; but, I wiſh the affair may not have a ſerious concluſion; for ſhe has a brother, a very ſpirited young fellow, who is a council in the Temple, and who will certainly call Belville to an account, the moment he hears of it.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: And what will become of the poor creature after he has deſerted her?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: You know that Belville is generous to profuſion, and has a thouſand good qualities to counter-balance this ſingle fault of gallantry, which contaminates his character.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: You men! you men!—You are ſuch wretches that there's no having a moment's ſatisfaction with you! and what's ſtill more provoking, there's no having a moment's ſatisfaction without you!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nay, don't think us all alike.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I'll endeavour to deceive myſelf; for it is but a poor argument of your ſincerity, to be the confidant of another's falſehood.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nay, no more of this, my love; no people live happier than Belville and his wife; nor is there a man in England, notwithſtanding all his levity, who conſiders his wife with a warmer degree of affection: if you have a friendſhip therefore, for her, let her continue in an error, ſo neceſſary to her repoſe, and give no hint, whatever, of his gallantries to any body.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: If I had no pleaſure in obliging you, I have too much regard for Mrs. Belville, not to follow your advice; but you need not enjoin me ſo ſtrongly on the ſubject, when you know I can keep a ſecret.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: You are all goodneſs; and the prudence with which you have conceal'd our private engagements, has eternally oblig'd me; had you truſted the ſecret even to Mrs. Belville, it wou'dn't have been ſafe; ſhe wou'd have told her huſband, and he is ſuch a rattleſkul, that, notwithſtanding all his regard for me, he wou'd have mention'd it in ſome moment of levity, and ſent it in a courſe of circulation to my father.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p:
The peculiarity of your father's temper, join'd to my want of fortune, made it neceſſary for me to keep our engagements inviolably ſecret; there is no merit, therefore, either in my prudence, or in my labouring aſſiduouſly to cultivate the good opinion of the General; ſince both were ſo • eceſſary
to my own happineſs; don't deſpiſe me for this acknowledgement now.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Bewitching ſoftneſs!—But your goodneſs, I flatter myſelf, will be ſpeedily rewarded; you are now ſuch a favourite with him, that he is eternally talking of you; and I really fancy he means to propoſe you to me himſelf: for, laſt night, in a few minutes after he had declared you would make the beſt wife in the world, he ſeriouſly aſk'd me if I had any averſion to matrimony?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why, that was a very great conceſſion indeed, as he ſeldom ſtoops to conſult any body's inclinations.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So it was, I aſſure you; for, in the army, being uſed to nothing but command and obedience, he removes the diſcipline of the parade into his family, and no more expects his orders ſhou'd be diſputed, in matters of a domeſtic nature, than if they were deliver'd at the head of his regiment.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: And yet, Mrs. Tempeſt, who you ſay is as much a ſtorm in her nature as her name, is diſputing them eternally.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, Miſs Walſingham, hav'n't we had a pretty morning's viſitor?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Really, I think ſo; and I have been aſking Capt. Savage, how long the lady has been diſordered in her ſenſes?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why will they let the poor woman abroad, without ſome body to take care of her?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, ſhe has her lucid intervals.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I declare I ſhall be as angry with you as I am with Belville. (aſide to the Captain.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: You can't think how ſenſibly ſhe ſpoke at firſt.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
I ſhould have had no conception of her madneſs,
if ſhe hadn't brought ſo prepoſterous a charge againſt me.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: Lady Rachel Mildew, Madam, ſends her compliments, and if you are not particularly engaged, will do herſelf the pleaſure of waiting upon you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Our compliments, and we ſhall be glad to ſee her Ladyſhip. Ex. Servant.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I wonder if Lady Rachel knows that Torrington came to town laſt night from Bath!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I hope he has found benefit by the waters, for he is one of the beſt creatures exiſting; he's a downright parſon Adams, in good nature and ſimplicity.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Lady Rachel will be quite happy at his return, and it would be a laughable affair, if a match could be brought about between the old maid and the old bachelor.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Mr. Torrington is too much taken up at Weſtminſter-Hall, to think of paying his devoirs to the ladies; and too plain a ſpeaker, I fancy, to be agreeable to Lady Rachel.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You miſtake the matter widely; ſhe is deeply ſmitten with him; but honeſt Torrington is utterly unconſcious of his conqueſt, and modeſtly thinks that he has not a ſingle attraction for any woman in the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Yet my poor aunt ſpeaks ſufficiently plain, in all conſcience, to give him a different opinion of himſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Yes, and puts her charms into ſuch repair, whenever ſhe expects to meet him, that her cheeks look for all the world like a raſberry ice upon a ground of cuſtard.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p:
I thought Apollo was the only god of Lady
Rachel's idolatary, and that in her paſſion for poetry ſhe had taken leave of all the leſs elevated affections.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O, you miſtake again; the poets are eternally in love, and can by no means be calculated to deſcribe the imaginary paſſions, without being very ſuſceptible of the real ones.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: The man, Madam, from Taviſtock-ſtreet, has brought home the dreſſes for the maſquerade, and deſires to know if there are any commands for him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O, bid him ſtay till we ſee the dreſſes.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: They are only Dominos.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am glad of that; for characters are as difficult to be ſupported at the maſquerade, as they are in real life. The laſt time I was at the Pantheon, a veſtal virgin invited me to ſup with her, and ſwore that her pocket had been pick'd by a Juſtice of peace.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Nay, that was not ſo bad, as the Hamlet's Ghoſt that box'd with Henry the Eighth, and afterwards danc'd a hornpipe to the tune of Nancy Dawſon. Ha! ha! ha!—We follow you, Mrs. Belville. Exeunt.

div.stage: Scene changes to LEESON's Chambers in the Temple:

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Where is this clerk of mine? Connolly!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: (behind) Here, Sir!

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Have you copied the marriage ſettlement, as I corrected it?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: (Enters with piſtols) Ay, honey, an hour ago.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What, you have been trying thoſe piſtols?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: By my ſoul, I have been firing them this half hour, without once being able to make them go off.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: They are plaguy dirty.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: In troth, ſo they are: I ſtrove to brighten them up a little, but ſome misfortune attends every thing I do, for the more I clane them, the dirtier they are, honey.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: You have had ſome of our uſual daily viſitors for money, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: You may ſay that; and three or four of them are now hanging about the door, that I wiſh handſomely hang'd any where elſe, for bodering us.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: No joking, Connolly! my preſent ſituation is a very diſagreeable one.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, and ſo it is; but who makes it diſareeable? your Aunt Tempeſt would let you have as much money as you pleaſe, but you won't condeſcend to be acquainted with her, though people in this country can be very intimate friends, without ſeeing one anothers faces for ſeven years.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Do you think me baſe enough to receive a favour from a woman, who has diſgraced her family, and ſtoops to be a kept miſtreſs? you ſee, my ſiſter is already ruin'd by a connection with her.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, a good guinea isn't the worſe for coming through a bad hand; if it was, what would become of us lawyers? and by my ſoul, many a high head in London would, at this minute, be very low, if they hadn't recieved favours even from much worſe people than kept miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Others, Connolly, may proſtitute their honour, as they pleaſe; mine is my chief poſſeſſion, and I muſt take particular care of it.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p:
Honour, to be ſure, is a very fine thing, Sir; but I don't ſee how it is to be taken care of, without a little money; your honour, to my knowledge, has'n't been in your own poſſeſſion theſe two
years, and the devil a crum can you honeſtly ſwear by, till you get it out of the hands of your creditors.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I have given you a licence to talk, Connolly, becauſe I know you faithful; but I hav'n't given you a liberty to ſport with my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: You know I'd die to ſerve you, Sir; but of what uſe is your giving me leave to ſpake, if you oblige me to hould my tongue? 'tis out of pure love and affection that I put you in mind of your misfortunes.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Well, Connolly, a few days will, in all probability, enable me to redeem my honour, and to reward your fidelity; the lovely Emily, you know, has half conſented to embrace the firſt opportunity of flying with me to Scotland, and the paltry trifles I owe, will not be miſs'd in her Fortune.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: But, dear Sir, conſider you are going to fight a duel this very evening, and if you ſhou'd be kilt, I fancy you will find it a little difficult, to run away afterwards with the lovely Emily.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: If I fall, there will be an end to my miſfortunes.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: But ſurely it will not be quite genteel, to go out of the world without paying your debts.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: But how ſhall I ſtay in the world, Connolly, without puniſhing Belville for ruining my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O, the devil fly away with this honour; an ounce of common ſenſe, is worth a whole ſhip load of it, if we muſt prefer a bullet or a halter, to a fine young lady and a great fortune.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: We'll talk no more on the ſubject at preſent. Take this letter to Mr. Belville; deliver it into his own hand, be ſure; and bring me an anſwer: make haſte; for I ſhall not ſtir out till you come back.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: By my ſoul, I wiſh you may be able to ſtir out then, honey.—O, but that's true!

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, the gentleman I laſt liv'd clerk
with, died lately and left me a legacy of twenty guineas—

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What! is Mr. Stanley dead?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, his friends have behav'd very unkindly if he is not, for they have buried him theſe ſix weeks.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I received my little legacy this morning, and if you'd be ſo good as to keep it for me, I'd be much oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Connolly, I underſtand you, but I am already ſhamefully in your debt: you've had no money from me this age.—

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O Sir, that does not ſignify; if you are not kilt in this damn'd duel, you'll be able enough to pay me: if you are, I ſhan't want it.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Why ſo, my poor fellow?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Becauſe, tho' I am but your clerk, and tho' I think fighting the moſt fooliſh thing upon earth, I'm as much a gintleman as yourſelf, and have as much right to commit a murder in the way of duelling.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And what then? You have no quarrel with Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I ſhall have a damn'd quarrel with him tho' if you are kilt: your death ſhall be reveng'd, depend upon it, ſo let that content you.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: My dear Connolly, I hope I ſhan't want ſuch a proof of your affection.—How he diſtreſſes me!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: You will want a ſecond, I ſuppoſe, in this affair: I ſtood ſecond to my own brother, in the Fifteen Acres, and tho' that has made me deteſt the very thought of duelling ever ſince; yet if you want a friend, I'll attend you to the field of death with a great deal of ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p:
I thank you, Connolly, but I think it extremely wrong in any man who has a quarrel, to expoſe
his friend to difficulties; we ſhou'dn't ſeek for redreſs, if we are not equal to the taſk of fighting our own battles; and I chooſe you particularly, to carry my letter becauſe, you may be ſuppoſed ignorant of the contents, and thought to be acting only in the ordinary courſe of your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Say no more about it, honey; I will be back with you preſently. (going, returns.) I put the twenty guineas in your pocket, before you were up, Sir; and I don't believe you'd look for ſuch a thing there, if I wasn't to tell you of it. Exit.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: This faithful, noble-hearted creature!— but let me fly from thought; the buſineſs I have to execute, will not bear the teſt of reflection. Exit.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: As this is a challenge, I ſhou'dn't go without a ſword; come down, little tickle-pitcher. (Takes a ſword.) Some people may think me very conceited now; but as the dirtieſt black legs in town can wear one without being ſtared at, I don't think it can ſuffer any diſgrace by the ſide of an honeſt man.

div.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment at BELVILLE'S.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p:
How ſtrangely this affair of Mrs. Tempeſt hangs upon my ſpirits, tho' I have every reaſon, from the tenderneſs, the politeneſs, and the generoſity of Mr. Belville, as well as from the woman's behaviour, to believe the whole charge the reſult of a diſturb'd imagination.—Yet ſuppoſe it ſhould be actually true:—heigho!—well, ſuppoſe it ſhou'd;—I wou'd endeavour—I think I wou'd endeavour to keep my temper:—a frowning face never recovered a heart that was not to be fix'd with a ſmiling one:—but women, in general, forget this grand article of the matrimonial
creed entirely; the dignity of inſulted virtue obliges them to play the fool, whenever their Corydons play the libertine;—and poh! they muſt pull down the houſe about the traitor's ears, tho' they are themſelves to be cruſh'd in pieces by the ruins.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: Lady Rachel Mildew, madam. Exit Ser.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: My dear, how have you done ſince the little eternity of my laſt ſeeing you. Mr. Torrington is come to town, I hear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: He is, and muſt be greatly flattered to find that your Ladyſhip has made him the hero of your new comedy.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Yes, I have drawn him as he is, an honeſt practitioner of the law; which is I fancy no very common character—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: And it muſt be a vaſt acquiſition to the Theatre.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Yet the managers of both houſes have refuſed my play; have refuſed it peremptorily! tho' I offer'd to make them a preſent of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: That's very ſurprizing, when you offer'd to make them a preſent of it.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: They alledge that the audiences are tired of crying at comedies; and inſiſt that my Deſpairing Shepherdeſs is abſolutely too diſmal for repreſentation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What, tho' you have introduced a lawyer in a new light?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Yes, and have a boarding-ſchool romp, that ſl • ps her mother's face, and throws a baſon of ſcalding water at her governeſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Why, ſurely, theſe are capital jokes!

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: But the managers can't find them out.—However, I am determined to bring it out ſomewhere; and I have diſcover'd ſuch a treaſure for my boarding-ſchool romp, as exceeds the moſt ſanguine expectation of criticiſm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: How fortunate!

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Goings to Mrs. Le Blond, my millener's, this morning, to ſee ſome contraband ſilks, (for you know there's a foreign miniſter juſt arriv'd) I heard a loud voice rehearſing Juliet, from the dining-room; and upon enquiry found that it was a country girl, juſt elop'd from her friends in town, to go upon the ſtage with an Iriſh manager.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Ten to one, the ſtrange woman's neice, who has been here this morning. aſide.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Mrs. Le Blond has ſome doubts about the manager it ſeems, though ſhe hasn't ſeen him yet, becauſe the apartments are very expenſive, and were taken by a fine gentleman out of livery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What am I to think of this?—Pray, Lady Rachel, as you have convers'd with this young actreſs, I ſuppoſe you could procure me a ſight of her.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: This moment if you will, I am very intimate with her already; but pray keep the matter a ſecret from your huſband, for he is ſo witty, you know, upon my paſſion for the drama, that I ſhall be teized to death by him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O, you may be very ſure that your ſecret is ſafe, for I have a moſt particular reaſon to keep it from Mr. Belville; but he is coming this way with Captain Savage, let us at preſent avoid him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p:
You are a very ſtrange man, Belville; you are for ever tremblingly ſolicitous about the happineſs
of your wife, yet for ever endangering it by your paſſion for variety.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, there is certainly a contradiction between my principles and my practice; but, if ever you marry, you'll be able to reconcile it perfectly. Poſſeſſion, Savage! O, poſſeſſion, is a miſerable whetter of the appetite in love! and I own myſelf ſo ſad a fellow, that though I wou'dn't exchange Mrs. Belville's mind for any woman's upon earth, there is ſcarcely a woman's perſon upon earth, which is not to me a ſtronger object of attraction.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Then perhaps in a little time you'll be weary of Miſs Leeſon?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: To be ſure I ſhall; though to own the truth, I have not yet carried my point concluſively with the little monkey.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Why how the plague has ſhe eſcap'd a moment in your hands?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: By a mere accident.—She came to the lodgings, which my man Spruce prepar'd for her, rather unexpectedly laſt night, ſo that I happened to be engaged particularly in another quarter—you underſtand me—and the damn'd aunt found me ſo much employment all the morning, that I could only ſend a meſſage by Spruce, promiſing to call upon her the firſt moment I had to ſpare in the courſe of the day.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And ſo your are previouſly ſatisfied that you ſhall be tired of her.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Tir'd of her?—Why I am at this moment in purſuit of freſh game, againſt the hour of ſatiety:—Game that you know to be exquiſite! and I fancy I ſhall bring it down, though it is cloſely guarded by a deal of that pride, which paſſes for virtue with the generallity of your mighty good people.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Indeed! and may a body know this wonder?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You are to be truſted with any thing, for you are the cloſeſt fellow I ever knew, and the rack itſelf would hardly make you diſcover one of your own ſecrets to any body—what do you think of Miſs Walſingham?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Miſs Walſingham?—Death and the devil!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Miſs Walſingham:

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Why ſurely ſhe has not received your addreſſes with any degree of approbation?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: With every degree of approbation I cou'd expect.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: She has?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ay: Why this news ſurpriſes you?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: It does indeed!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I can't help laughing to think what a happy dog Miſs Walſingham's huſband is likely to be!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: A very happy dog, truly!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She's a delicious girl, is'n't ſhe, Savage?— but ſhe'll require a little more trouble;—for a fine woman, like a fortified town, to ſpeak in your father's language, demands a regular ſiege; and we muſt even allow her the honours of war, to magnify the greatneſs of our own victory.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Well, it amazes me how you gay fellows ever have the preſumption to attack a woman of principle; Miſs Walſingham has no apparent levity of any kind about her.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No; but ſhe continued in my houſe, after I had whiſpered my paſſion in her ear, and gave me a ſecond opportunity of addreſſing her improperly; what greater encouragement cou'd I deſire?
Well, Spruce, what are your commands?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: My Lady is juſt gone out with Lady Rachel, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: I believe you do. (Aſide.) Exit.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What is the Engliſh of theſe ſignificant looks between Spruce and you?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Only that Miſs Walſingham is left alone, and that I have now an opportunity of entertaining her; you muſt excuſe me, Savage; you muſt upon my ſoul; but not a word of this affair to any body; becauſe when I ſhake her off my hands, there may be fools enough to think of her, upon terms of honourable matrimony. Exit

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So, here's a diſcovery! a precious diſcovery! and while I have been racking my imagination, and ſacrificing my intereſt, to promote the happineſs of this woman, ſhe has been liſtening to the addreſſes of another; to the addreſſes of a married man! the huſband of her friend, and the immediate friend of her intended huſband!—By Belville's own account, however, ſhe has not yet proceeded to any criminal lengths—But why did ſhe keep the affair a ſecret from me? or why did ſhe continue in his houſe after a repeated declaration of his unwarrantable attachment?—What's to be done?—If I open my engagement with her to Belville, I am ſure he will inſtantly deſiſt;—but then her honour is left in a ſtate extremely queſtionable—It ſhall be ſtill concealed— While it remains unknown, Belville will himſelf tell me every thing;—and doubt, upon an occaſion of this nature, is infinitely more inſupportable than the downright falſehood of the woman whom we love.

div.trailer: The END of the FIRST ACT.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: SCENE, an Apartment in General SAVAGE's Houſe.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: ZOUNDS! Torrington, give me quarter, when I ſurrender up my ſword: I own that for theſe twenty years, I have been ſuffering all the inconveniences of marriage, without taſting any one of its comforts, and rejoicing in an imaginary freedom, while I was really grovelling in chains.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: In the dirtieſt chains upon earth;—yet you wou'dn't be convinc'd, but laugh'd at all your married acquaintance as ſlaves, when not one of them put up with half ſo much from the worſt wife, as you were oblig'd to crouch under, from a kept miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: 'Tis too true. But, you know, ſhe ſacrificed much for me;—you know that ſhe was the widow of a colonel, and refus'd two very advantageous matches on my account.—

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: If ſhe was the widow of a judge, and had refuſed a high chancellor, ſhe was ſtill a devil incarnate, and you were of courſe a madman to live with her.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You don't remember her care of me when I have been ſick.—

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I recollect, however, her uſage of you in health, and you may eaſily find a tenderer nurſe, when you are bound over by the gout or the rheumatiſm.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well, well, I agree with you that ſhe is a devil incarnate; but I am this day determin'd to part with her for ever.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Not you indeed.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What, don't I know my own mind?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Not you indeed, when ſhe is in the queſtion; with every body elſe, your reſolution is as unalterable as a determination in the houſe of peers; but Mrs. Tempeſt is your fate, and ſhe reverſes your decrees with as little difficulty as a fraudulent debtor now-a-days procures his certificate under a commiſſion of bankruptcy.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well if, like the Roman Fabius, I conquer by delay, in the end, there will be no great reaſon to find fault with my generalſhip. The propoſal of parting now comes from herſelf.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: O, you darn't make it for the life of you.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You muſt know that this morning we had a ſmart cannonnading on Belville's account, and ſhe threatens, as I told you before, to quit my houſe if I don't challenge him for taking away her neice.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: That fellow is the very devil among the women, and yet there isn't a man in England fonder of his wife.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Poh, if the young minx hadn't ſurrender'd to him, ſhe would have capitulated to ſomebody elſe, and I ſhall at this time be doubly obliged to him, if he is any ways inſtrumentall in getting the aunt off my hands.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why at this time?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Becauſe to ſhew you how fix'd my reſolution is to be a keeper no longer, I mean to marry immediately.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And can't you avoid being preſs'd to death, like a felon who refuſes to plead, without incurring a ſentence of perpetual impriſonment?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
I fancy you would yourſelf have no objection
to a perpetual impriſonment in the arms of Miſs Walſingham.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: But have you any reaſon to think that upon examination in a caſe of love, ſhe would give a favourable reply to your interrogatories?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The greateſt—do you think I'd hazard ſuch an engagement without being perfectly ſure of my ground? Notwithſtanding my preſent connection won't ſuffer me to ſee a modeſt woman at my own houſe—She always treats me with particular attention whenever I viſit at Belville's, or meet her any where elſe—If fifty young fellows are preſent, ſhe directs all her aſſiduities to the old ſoldier, and my ſon has a thouſand times told me that ſhe profeſſes the higheſt opinion of my underſtanding.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And truly you give a notable proof of your underſtanding, in thinking of a woman almoſt young enough to be your grand-daughter.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Nothing like an experienc'd chief to command in any garriſon.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Recollect the ſtate of your preſent citadel.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well, if I am blown up by my own mine, I ſhall be the only ſufferer—There's another thing I want to talk of, I am going to marry my ſon to Miſs Moreland.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Miſs Moreland!—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Belville's ſiſter.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: O, ay, I remember that Moreland had got a good eſtate to aſſume the name of Belville.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I have'nt yet mention'd the matter to my ſon, but I ſettled the affair with the girl's mother yeſterday, and ſhe only waits to communicate it to Belville, who is her oracle, you know.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And are you ſure the captain will like her?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am not ſo unreaſonable as to inſiſt upon his liking her, I ſhall only inſiſt upon his marrying her.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: What, whether he likes her or not?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: When I iſſue my orders, I expect them to be obey'd; and don't look for an examination into their propriety.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: What a delightful thing it muſt be to live under a military government, where a man is not to be troubled with the exerciſe of his underſtanding.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Miſs Moreland has thirty thouſand pounds— That's a large ſum of ammunition money.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay, but a marriage merely on the ſcore of fortune, is only gilding the death-warrant ſent down for the execution of a priſoner. However as I know your obſtinate attachment to what you once reſolve, I ſhan't pretend to argue with you; where are the papers which you want me to conſider?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: They are in my library—File off with me to the next room and they ſhall be laid before you— But firſt I'll order the chariot, for the moment I have your opinion, I purpoſe to ſit down regularly before Miſs Walſingham—who waits there?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Is Mrs. Tempeſt at home?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, juſt come in, and juſt going out again.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Very well; order the chariot to be got ready.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir, one of the pannels was broke laſt night at the Opera-houſe.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Sir, I didn't call to have the pleaſure of your converſation, but to have obedience paid to my orders.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Go order the chariot, you blockhead.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: With the broken pannel, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Yes, you raſcal, if both pannels were broke, and the back ſhattered to pieces.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: The coachman thinks that one of the wheels is damag'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
Don't attempt to reaſon, you dog, but execute
your orders.—Bring the chariot without the wheels—if you can't bring it with them.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay bring it, if you reduce it to a ſledge, and let your maſter look like a malefactor for high treaſon, on his journey to Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: General Savage, is the houſe to be for ever a ſcene of noiſe with your domineering?— The chariot ſhan't be brought—it won't be fit for uſe 'till it is repaired—and John, ſhall drive it this very minute to the coach-makers.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Nay, my dear, if it isn't fit for uſe that's another thing.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Here's the experienced chief that's fit to command in any garr ••• n. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Go order me the coach then. to the Ser.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: You can't have the coach.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And why ſo, my love.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Becauſe I want it for myſelf.—Robert, get a hack for your maſter—tho' indeed I don't ſee what buſineſs he has • ut of the houſe.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: When you iſſu • your orders, you expect them to be • b • y'd, and don't look for an examination into their propriety.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The fury!—this has ſteel'd me againſt her for ever, and nothing on earth can now prevent me from drumming her out immediately.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: (behind) An unreaſonable old fool— But I'll make him know who governs this houſe!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Zounds! here ſhe comes again; ſhe has been lying in ambuſcade, I ſuppoſe, and has over heard us.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: What if ſhe has? you are ſteel'd againſt her for ever.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
No, ſhe's not coming—ſhe's going down
ſtairs;—and now, dear Torrington, you muſt be as ſilent as a ſentinel on an out-poſt about this affair. If that virago was to hear a ſyllable of it, ſhe might perhaps attack Miſs Walſingham in her very camp, and defeat my whole plan of operations.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I thought you were determin'd to drum her out immediately. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Miſs WALSINGHAM, followed by BELVILLE.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I beg, Sir, that you will inſult me no longer with ſolicitations of this nature—Give me proofs of your ſincerity indeed! What proofs of ſincerity can your ſituation admit of, if I could be even weak enough to think of you with partiality at all?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: If our affections, Madam, were under the government of our reaſon, circumſtanced as I am, this unhappy boſom wouldn't be torn by paſſion for Miſs Walſingham.—Had I been bleſs'd with your acquaintance, before I ſaw Mrs. Belville, my hand as well as my heart, wou'd have been humbly offer'd to your acceptance—fate, however, has ordered it otherwiſe, and it is cruel to reproach me with that ſituation as a crime, which ought to be pitied as my greateſt misfortune.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: He's actually forcing tears into his eyes.—However, I'll mortify him ſeverely. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But ſuch proofs of ſincerity as my ſituation can admit of, you ſhall yourſelf command, as my only buſineſs in exiſtence is to adore you.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: His only buſineſs in exiſtence to adore me. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Proſtrate at your feet, my deareſt Miſs Walſingham (kneeling) behold a heart eternally devoted to your ſervice.—You have too much good ſenſe, Madam, to be the ſlave of cuſtom, and too much humanity not to pity the wretchedneſs you have
cauſed.—Only, therefore, ſay that you commiſerate my ſufferings—I'll aſk no more—and ſurely that may be ſaid, without any injury to your purity, to ſnatch even an enemy from diſtraction—where's my handkerchief? aſide.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Now to anſwer in his own way, and to make him ridiculous to himſelf— (aſide.) If I thought, if I could think (affecting to weep) that theſe proteſtations were real.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: How can you, Madam, be ſo unjuſt to your own merit? how can you be ſo cruelly doubtful of my ſolemn aſſeverations?—Here I again kneel, and ſwear eternal love!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I don't know what to ſay—but there is one proof— (affecting to weep.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Name it, my angel, this moment, and make me the happieſt of mankind!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Swear to be mine for ever.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have ſworn it a thouſand times, my charmer; and I will ſwear it to the laſt moment of my life.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why then—but don't look at me I beſeech you—I don't know how to ſpeak it—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The delicious emotion—do not check the generous tide of tenderneſs that fills me with ſuch extaſy.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: You'll deſpiſe me for this weakneſs.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This weakneſs—this generoſity which will demand my everlaſting gratitude.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I am a fool—but there is a kind of fatality in this affair—and I do conſent to go off with you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Eternal bleſſings on your condeſcenſion.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: You are irreſiſtible, and I am ready to fly with you to any part of the world.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Fly to any part of the world indeed—you ſhall fly by yourſelf then; (aſide.) You are the
moſt lovely, the moſt tender creature in the world, and thus again let me thank you: O, Miſs Walſingham, I cannot expreſs how happy you've made me!—But where's the neceſſity of our leaving England?—

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I thought he wouldn't like to go abroad— (aſide.) That I may poſſeſs the pleaſure of your company unrival'd.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I muſt cure her of this taſte for travelling—

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: You don't anſwer, Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why I was turning the conſequence of your propoſal in my thoughts, as going off—going off— you know.—

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why going off, you know, is going off— And what objections can you have to going off?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why going off, will ſubject you at a certainty, to the ſlander of the world; whereas by ſtaying at home, we may not only have numberleſs opportunities of meeting, but at the ſame time prevent ſuſpicion it ſelf, from ever breathing on your reputation.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I didn't dream of your ſtarting any difficulties, Sir.—Juſt now I was dearer to you than all the world.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And ſo you are, by heav'n!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why won't you ſacrifice the world then at once to obtain me?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Surely, my deareſt life, you muſt know the neceſſity, which every man of honour is under of keeping up his character?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p:
So, here's this fellow ſwearing to ten thouſand lies, and yet talking very gravely about his honour and his character. (aſide.) Why, to be ſure in theſe days, Mr. Belville, the inſtances of conjugal infidelity are ſo very ſcarce, and men of faſhion are ſo remarkable for a tender attachment to their wives, that I don't wonder at your circumſpection—But do
you think I can ſtoop to accept you by halves, or admit of any partnerſhip in your heart?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O you muſt do more than that, if you have any thing to ſay to me. (aſide.) Surely, Madam, when you know my whole ſoul unalterably your own, you will permit me to preſerve thoſe appearances with the world, which are indiſpenſibly requiſite—Mrs. Belville is a moſt excellent woman, however it may be my fortune to be devoted to another—Her happineſs, beſides, conſtitutes a principal part of my felicity, and if I was publicly to forſake her, I ſhould be hunted as a monſter from ſociety.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Then, I ſuppoſe, it is by way of promoting Mrs. Belville's repoſe, Sir, that you make love to other women; and by way of ſhewing the nicety of your honour, that you attempt the purity of ſuch as your own roof, peculiarly, intitles to protection. For the honour intended to me—thus low to the ground, I thank you, Mr. Belville.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Laugh'd at, by all the ſtings of mortification▪

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Good bye.—Don't let this accident mortify your vanity too much;—but take care, the next time you vow everlaſting love, that the object is neither tender enough to ſob—ſob—at your diſtreſs; nor provoking enough to make a propoſal of leaving England.—How greatly a little common ſenſe can lower theſe fellows of extraordinary impudence?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
(alone.) So then, I am fairly taken in, and ſhe has been only diverting herſelf with me all this time:— however, lady fair, I may chance to have the laugh in a little time on my ſide; for if you can ſport in this manner about the flame, I think it muſt in the run lay hold of your wings:—what ſhall I do in this affair?—ſhe ſees the matter in its true light, and there's no good to be expected from thumping of boſoms, or ſqueezing white handkerchiefs;—no theſe
won't do with women of ſenſe, and in a ſhort time, they'll be ridiculous to the very babies of a boarding-ſchool.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Well, Belville, what news? You have had a freſh opportunity with Miſs Walſingham.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, faith, Savage, I've had a moſt extraordinary ſcene with her, and yet have but little reaſon to brag of my good fortune, tho' ſhe offer'd in expreſs terms to run away with me.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Prith'ee explain yourſelf, man; ſhe cou'dn't ſurely be ſo ſhameleſs!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O, her offering to run away with me, was by no means the worſt part of the affair.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: No, then it muſt be damn'd bad indeed! but prith'ee, hurry to an explanation.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why then, the worſt part of the affair is, that ſhe was laughing at me the whole time; and made this propoſal of an elopement, with no other view, than to ſhew me in ſtrong colours to myſelf, as a very dirty fellow to the beſt wife in England.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am eaſy. aſide.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Sir, there is an Iriſh gentleman below with a letter for you, who will deliver it to nobody but yourſelf.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Shew him up then.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: It may be on buſineſs Belville, I'll take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O, by no means; I can have no buſineſs which I deſire to keep from you, tho' you are the arrant'ſt miſer of your confidence upon earth, and wou'd rather truſt your life in any body's hands, than even a paltry amour with the apprentice of a millener.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Gintlemin, your moſt obedient; pray which of you is Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My name is Belville, at your ſervice, Sir.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I have a little bit of a letter for you, Sir.

body.p: The people where Miſs Leeſon lately lodg'd, aſſerting poſitively that you have taken her away in a fictitious character, the brother of that unhappy girl, thinks himſelf oblig'd to demand ſatisfaction, for the injury which you have done his family; tho' a ſtranger to your perſon, he is ſufficiently acquainted with your reputation for ſpirit, and ſhall, therefore, make no doubt of ſeeing you with a caſe of piſtols, near the Ring in Hyde Park, at eight o'clock this evening, to anſwer the claims of

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Eight o'clock in the evening! 'tis a ſtrange time!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why ſo, honey? A fine evening is as good a time for a bad action as a fine morning; and if a man of ſenſe can be ſuch a fool as to fight a duel, he ſhou'd never ſleep upon the matter, for the more he thinks of it, the more he muſt feel himſelf aſham'd of his reſolution.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: A pretty letter!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O yes, an invitation to a brace of bullets is a very pretty thing.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: For a challenge, however, 'tis very civilly written!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, if it was written to me, I ſhou'dn't be very fond of ſuch civility; I wonder he doesn't ſign himſelf, your moſt obedient ſervant.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I told you Leeſon's character, and what wou'd become of this damn'd buſineſs; but your affairs—are they ſettled, Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O they are always ſettled—for as this is a country where people occaſionally die, I take conſtant care to be prepared for contingencies.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Occaſionally die!—I'll be very much oblig'd to you; Sir, if you tell me the country where people do not die? for I'll immediately go and end my days there.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CON,
sp.p: Faith, you may laugh gintlemin, but tho' I am a fooliſh Iriſhman, and come about a fooliſh piece of buſineſs, I'd prefer a ſnug birth in this world, bad as it is, to the fineſt coffin in all Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am ſurpris'd, Sir, that thinking in this manner, you would be the bearer of a challenge.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And well you may, Sir.—But we muſt often take a pleaſure in ſerving our friends, by doing things that are very diſagreeable to us.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Then you think Mr. Leeſon much to blame, perhaps, for hazarding his life where he can by no means repair the honour of his ſiſter.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Indeed and I do—But I ſhall think this gintleman, begging his pardon, much more to blame for meeting him:

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And why ſo, Sir—You woudn't have me diſappoint your friend?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, and that I wou'd—He, poor lad, may have ſome reaſon at preſent to be tir'd of the world, but you have a fine eſtate, a fine wife, a fine parcel of children.—In ſhort, honey, you have every thing to make you fond of living, and the devil burn me, was I in your caſe, if I'd ſtake my own happineſs againſt the miſery of any man.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
I am very much oblig'd to your advice, Sir, tho' on the preſent occaſion I cannot adopt it; be ſo
good as to preſent my compliments to your friend, and tell him I ſhall certainly do myſelf the honour of attending his appointment.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why then upon my ſoul I am very ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: 'Tis not very cuſtomary, Sir, with gentlemen of Ireland to oppoſe an affair of honour.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: They are like the gintlemin of England, Sir, they are brave to a fault; yet I hope to ſee the day that it will be infamous to draw the ſwords of either, againſt any body but the enemies of their country.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am quite charmed with this honeſt Hibernian, and would almoſt fight a duel for the pleaſure of his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Come, ſtep with me a little, and let us conſider, whether there may not be ſome method of accommodating this curſed buſineſs.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Poh! don't be uneaſy upon my account; my character, with regard to affairs of this nature, is unhappily too well eſtabliſhed, and you may be ſure that I ſhan't fight with Leeſon.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: No—you have injured him greatly?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The very reaſon of all others why I ſhould not cut his throat. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: What, the devil, this maſter of mine has got a a duel upon his hands! Zounds! I am ſorry for that; he is a prince of a fellow! and a good ſubject muſt always love his prince, though he may now and then be a little out of humour with his actions.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Your hall-door ſtanding open, Spruce, and none of your ſentinels being on guard, I have ſurpriſed your camp thus far without reſiſtance: Where is your maſter?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Juſt gone out with Captain Savage, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Is your lady at home?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: No, Sir, but Miſs Walſingham is at home; ſhall I inform her of your viſit?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: There is no occaſion to inform her of it, for here ſhe is, Spruce. Exit Spruce.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: General Savage, your moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: My dear Miſs Walſingham, it is rather cruel that you ſhould be left at home by yourſelf, and yet I am greatly rejoic'd to find you at preſent without company.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I can't but think myſelf in the beſt company, when I have the honour of your converſation, General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You flatter me too much, Madam; yet I am come to talk to you on a ſerious affair, Miſs Walſingham; an affair of importance to me and to yourſelf: Have you leiſure to favour me with a ſhort audience, if I beat a parley?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Any thing of importance to you, Sir, is always ſufficient to command my leiſure.—'Tis as the Captain ſuſpected. aſide.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You tremble, my lovely girl, but don't be alarmed; for though my buſineſs is of an important nature, I hope it won't be of a diſagreeable one.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: And yet I am greatly agitated. aſide.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Soldiers, Miſs Walſingham, are ſaid to be generally favour'd by the kind partiality of the ladies.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: The ladies are not without gratitude, Sir, to thoſe who devote their lives peculiarly to the ſervice of their country.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
Generouſly ſaid, Madam: Then give me leave, without any maſked battery, to aſk, if the heart
of an honeſt ſoldier is a prize at all worth your acceptance.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, there's no maſked battery in this queſtion.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am as fond of a coup de main, Madam, in love, as in war, and hate the tedious method of ſapping a town, when there is a poſſibility of entering ſword in hand.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why really, Sir, a woman may as well know her own mind, when ſhe is firſt ſummoned by the trumpet of a lover, as when ſhe undergoes all the tireſome formality of a ſiege. You ſee I have caught your own mode of converſing, General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And a very great compliment I conſider it, Madam: But now that you have candidly confeſs'd an acquaintance with your own mind, anſwer me with that frankneſs for which every body admires you ſo much. Have you any objection to change the name of Walſingham?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why then frankly, General Savage I ſay, no.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Ten thouſand thanks to you for this kind declaration.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I hope you won't think it a forward one.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I'd ſooner ſee my ſon run away in the day of battle;—I'd ſooner think Lord Ruſſell was bribed by Lewis the XIVth, and ſooner villify the memory of Algernoon Sidney.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: How unjuſt it was ever to ſuppoſe the General a tyrannical father! aſide.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You have told me condeſcendingly, Miſs Walſingham, that you have no objection to change your name, I have but one queſtion more to aſk.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Pray propoſe it.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Would the name of Savage be diſagreeable to you?—Speak frankly again, my dear girl!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why then again I frankly ſay, no.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You make me too happy; and though I ſhall readily own, that a propoſal of this nature would come with more propriety from my ſon—

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I am much better pleas'd that you make the propoſal yourſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You are too good to me.—Torrington thought that I ſhould meet with a repulſe. aſide.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Have you communicated this buſineſs to the Captain, Sir?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: No, my dear Madam, I did not think that at all neceſſary. I have always been attentive to the Captain's happineſs, and I propoſe that he ſhall be married in a few days.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: What, whether I will or no?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O you can have no objection.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I muſt be conſulted, however, about the day, General: but nothing in my power ſhall be wanting to make him happy.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Obliging lovelineſs!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: You may imagine, that if I was not previouſly impreſt in favour of your propoſal, it wou'd not have met my concurrence ſo readily.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Then you own that I had a previous friend in the garriſon.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I don't bluſh to acknowledge it, when I conſider the accompliſhments of the object, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O this is too much, Madam; the principle merit of the object is his paſſion for Miſs Walſingham.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Don't ſay that, General, I beg of you, for I don't think there are many women in the kingdom, who could behold him with indifference.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Ah, you flattering, flattering angel!—and yet, by the memory of Marlborough, my lovely girl, it was the idea of a prepoſſeſſion on your part, which encouraged me to hope for a favourable reception.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Then I muſt have been very indiſcreet, for I labour'd to conceal that prepoſſeſſion as much as poſſible.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You cou'dn't conceal it from me! you cou'dn't conceal it from me!—The female heart is a field which I am thoroughly acquainted with, and which has more than once been a witneſs to my victories, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I don't at all doubt your ſucceſs with the ladies, General; but as we now underſtand one another ſo perfectly, you will give me leave to retire.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: One word, my dear creature, and no more; I ſhall wait upon you ſometime to day, with Mr. Torrington, about the neceſſary ſettlements.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: You muſt do as you pleaſe, General, you are invincible in every thing.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And if you pleaſe, we'll keep every thing a profound ſecret, 'till the articles are all ſettled, and the definitive treaty ready for execution.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: You may be ſure, that delicacy will not ſuffer me to be communicate on the ſubject, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Then you leave every thing to my management.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I can't truſt a more noble negociator.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The day's my own. (ſings.) Britons, ſtrike home! ſtrike home! Revenge, &c. Exit ſinging.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Enter Lady RACHEL MILDEW, Mrs. BELVILLE, and Miſs LEESON.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: WELL, Mrs. Belville, I am extremely glad you agree with me, in opinion of this young lady's qualifications for the ſtage. Don't you think ſhe'd play Miſs Headſtrong admirably in my comedy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, I think ſhe poſſeſſes a natural fund of ſpirit, very much adapted to the character.—'Tis impoſſible, ſurely, that this hoyden can have a moment's attraction for Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: You are very obliging, ladies; but I have no turn for comedy; my fort is tragedy entirely.
sp.q: Alphonſo!—O, Alphonſo! to thee I call. &c.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: But, my dear, is there none of our comedies to your taſte?

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: O, yes; ſome of the ſentimental ones are very pretty, there's ſuch little difference between them and tragedies.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: And pray, my dear, how long have you been engaged to Mr. Frankly?

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: I only came away laſt night, and hav'n't ſeen Mr. Frankly ſince, tho' I expect him every moment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Laſt night! juſt as Mrs. Tempeſt mentioned. aſide.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You had the concurrence of your friends?

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: Not I, Madam. Mr. Frankly ſaid, I had too much genius to mind my friends, and as I ſhould want nothing from them, there was no occaſion to conſult them in the affair.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Then Oſbaldiſton is not your real name, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: O no, nor do I tell my real name: I choſe Oſbaldiſton, becauſe it was a long one, and wou'd make a ſtriking appearance in the bills.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I wiſh we cou'd ſee Mr. Frankly.

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: Perhaps you may, Madam, for he deſigns to give me a leſſon every day, 'till we are ready to ſet off for Ireland.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Suppoſe then, my dear, you wou'd oblige us with a ſcene in Juliet, by way of ſhewing your proficiency to Mrs. Belville.

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: Will you ſtand up for Romeo?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: With all my heart, and I'll give you ſome inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: I beg pardon, Ma'am; I'll learn to act under nobody but Mr. Frankly. This room is without a carpet; if you will ſtep into the next, ladies, I'll endeavour to oblige you.
sp.q: Shall I not be environed, diſtraught—
sp.p: This way, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, ſhew us the way.

div.stage: Exeunt Miſs LEES. and Lady RACH.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I'll prolong this mummery as much as poſſible, in hopes the manager may come. Lye ſtill, poor fluttering heart! it cannot be the lord of all your wiſhes! it cannot ſurely be your ador'd Belville! Exit.

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: Hav'n't I left my Romeo and Juliet here? O yes, there it is.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: —O, were thoſe eyes in heav'n,

l.hi: They'd thro' the ſtarry regions ſtream ſo bright,
That birds wou'd ſing, and think it was the morn!

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Mr. Frankly! I am ſo glad you are come! I was dying to ſee you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Kiſs me, my dear;—why didn't you ſend me word of your intention to come away laſt night?

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: I hadn't time: but as I knew where the lodgings were, I thought I ſhou'd be able to find you by a note to the coffee-houſe I always directed to.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Kiſs me again, my little ſparkler!

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: Nay, I won't be kiſs'd in this manner; for tho' I am going on the ſtage, I intend to have ſome regard for my character. But, ha, ha, ha, I am glad you are come now: I have company above ſtairs.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Company! that's unlucky at this time, for I wanted to make you intirely eaſy about your character. (aſide.) And pray, my dear, who is your company? You know we muſt be very cautious for fear of your relations.

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: O, they are only ladies.—But one of them is the moſt beautiful creature in the world!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The devil ſhe is!

p.hi: An earth-treading ſtar, that makes dim heav'ns light.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds! I'll take a peep at the ſtar, who knows but I may have an opporturiity of making another actreſs. aſide.

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: Come, charmer! charmer!

sp.speaker: BEL.

q.l: As that vaſt ſhore, waſh'd by the fartheſt ſea,
I wou'd adventure for ſuch merchandize.

sp.p: Now let's ſee what fortune has ſent us above ſtairs.

div.stage: SCENE changes to a Dining-room at Miſs LEESON's.
Mrs. BELVILLE and Lady RACHEL diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: This is a moſt ignorant young creature, Lady Rachel.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Why I think ſhe is—did you obſerve how ſhe ſlighted my offer of inſtructing her?

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: Ladies!—ladies!—here he is! here is Mr. Frankly!

div.stage: Enter Belville, bowing very low, not ſeeing the Ladies.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ladies, your moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Let me, if poſſible, recollect myſelf— Sir, your moſt obedient humble ſervent.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds! let me out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: What do I ſee!

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: You ſeem, ladies, to know this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: (taking hold of him) You ſhan't go renegade—You laugh'd at my credulity this morning, and I muſt now laugh at your embaraſſment.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What a kind thing it would be in any body to blow out my ſtupid brains?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I'll mark this down for an incident in my comedy.

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: What do you hang your head for Mr. Frankley?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Be ſo good as to aſk that lady, my dear.— The Devil has been long in my debt, and now he pays me home with a witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What a cruel thing it is to let Mrs. Tempeſt out, my love, without ſomebody to take care of her!

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: What, do you know Mrs. Tempeſt, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Yes, my dear;—and I am pretty well acquainted with this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: What isn't this gentleman the manager of a play-houſe in Ireland?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The curtain is almoſt dropt my dear; the farce is nearly over, and you'll be ſpeedily acquainted with the cataſtrophe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the curtain is almoſt dropt: I have had ſpies to watch your haunts, and the cataſtrophe ends in your detection.—Come, you abandon'd ſlut,—

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: And have I elop'd after all, without being brought upon the ſtage?

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: I don't know that you would be brought upon the ſtage; but I am ſure you were near being brought upon the town. I hope, madam, for the future, you'll ſet me down a mad-woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Mr. Belvill, you'll make my apologies to this lady, and acknowledge that I think her perfectly in her ſenſes.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I wiſh that I had intirely loſt mine.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: (Writing) I wiſh that I had entirely loſt mine. A very natural wiſh, in ſuch a ſituation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEM.
sp.p: Come, you audacious minx, come away. You ſhall be ſent into Yorkſhire this very evening; and ſee what your poor mother will ſay to you, huſſey.

sp.speaker: Miſs LEES.
sp.p: I will go on the ſtage, if I die for't; and 'tis ſome comfort there's a play-houſe at York.

div.stage: Exit Mrs. Tempeſt and Miſs Leeſon.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Nancy, I am ſo aſham'd, ſo humbled, and ſo penitent, that if you knew what paſſes here, I am ſure you wou'd forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: My love, tho' I cannot ſay I rejoice in your infidelity, yet, believe me, I pity your diſtreſs: let us therefore think no more of this.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: (Writing.) And think no more of this. —This conduct is new in a wife, and very dramatic.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where, my angel, have you acquired ſo many requiſites to charm with?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: In your ſociety, my dear; and believe me —that a wife may be as true a friend as any bottle companion upon earth, tho' ſhe can neither get merry with you over night, nor blow out your brains about ſome fooliſh quarrel in the morning.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: If wives knew the omnipotence of virtue, where ſhe wears a ſmile upon her face, they'd all follow your bewitching example, and make a faithleſs huſband quite an incredible character.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Quite an incredible character!— Let me ſet down that. (writing.) Exeunt.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Yes, Horace, I have been juſt viſiting at Belvill's.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: You found nobody at home, but Miſs Walſingham?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: No, but I'd a long converſation with her, and upon a very intereſting ſubject.

sp.speaker: CAPT
sp.p: 'Tis as I gueſs'd. aſide.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: She is a moſt amiable creature, Horace.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So ſhe is, Sir, and will make any man happy that marries her.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am glad you think ſo.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: He's glad I think ſo!—'tis plain,—but I muſt leave every thing to himſelf, and ſeem wholly paſſive in the affair. aſide.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: A married life after all, Horace, I am now convinced is the moſt happy, as well as the moſt reputable.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: It is indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Then perhaps you wou'd have no objection to be married, if I offered you as agreeable a young woman as Miſs Walſingham.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be my firſt pride on every occaſion, Sir, to pay an implicit obedience to your commands.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: That's ſenſibly ſaid, Horace, and obligingly ſaid; prepare yourſelf therefore for an introduction to the lady in the morning.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Is the lady prepar'd to receive me, Sir?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O yes; and you can't think how highly delighted Miſs Walſingham appeared, when I acquainted her with my reſolution on the ſubject.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: She's all goodneſs!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The more I know her, the more I am charm'd with her; I muſt not be explicit with him yet, for fear my ſecret ſhould get wind, and reach the ears of the enemy. aſide.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I propoſe, Horace, that you ſhould be married immediately.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The ſooner the better, Sir, I have no will but your's.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (Shaking hands with him,) By the memory of Malbro', you are a moſt excellent boy!—But what do you think? Miſs Walſingham inſiſts upon naming the day.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And welcome, Sir; I am ſure ſhe won't make it a diſtant one.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O ſhe ſaid, that nothing in her power ſhou'd be wanting to make you happy.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am ſure of that, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: [A loud knocking] Zounds, Horace! here's the diſgrace and puniſhment of my life: Let's avoid her as we would a fever in the camp.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Come to the library, and I'll tell you how whimſically ſhe was treated this morning at Belville's.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Death and the devil! make haſte. O I muſt laugh at marriage, and be curſt to me! But I am providing, Horace, againſt your falling into my error.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am eternally indebted to you, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Belville and Lady Rachel.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Nay; Mrs. Belville, I have no patience, you act quite unnaturally.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What! becauſe I am unwilling to be miſerable?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: This new inſtance of Mr. Belville's infidelity—This attempt to ſeduce Miſs Walſingham, which your woman overheard, is unpardonable!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I don't ſay but that I am ſtrongly wounded by his irregularities. Yet if Mr. Belville is unhappily a rover, I wou'd much rather that he ſhould have twenty miſtreſſes than one.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Why, don't you know, my dear madam, that while he is divided amidſt a variety of objects, 'tis impoſſible for him to have a ſerious attachment?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Lord, Mrs. Belville! how can you ſpeak with ſo much compoſure! a virtuous woman ſhould be always outrageous upon ſuch an occaſion as this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What, and weary the innocent ſun and moon from the firmament, like a deſpairing princeſs in a tragedy—No—no—Lady Rachel, 'tis bad enough to be indifferent to the man I love, without ſtudying to excite his averſion.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: How glad I am that Miſs Walſingham made him ſo heartily aſham'd of himſelf: Lord, theſe young men are ſo full of levity: Give me a huſband of Mr. Torrington's age, ſay I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: And give me a huſband of Mr. Belville's, ſay I, with all his follies: However, Lady Rachel, I am pretty well ſatisfied that my conduct at Miſs Leeſon's will have a proper effect upon Mr. Belville's generoſity, and put an entire end to his galantries for the future.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Don't deceive yourſelf, my dear.— The gods in the ſhilling gallery would ſooner give up Roaſt Beef, or go without an epilogue on the firſt night of a new piece.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Why ſhould you, think ſo of ſuch a man as Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Becauſe Mr. Belville is a man: However, if you dare run the riſque—we will try the ſincerity of his reformation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: If I dare run the riſque! I would ſtake my ſoul upon his honour.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Then your poor ſoul would be in a very terrible ſituation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: By what teſt can we prove his ſincerity?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: By a very ſimple one. You know I write ſo like Miſs Walſingham, that our hands are ſcarcely known aſunder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Well—

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Why then let me write to him as from her—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: If I did not think it would look like a doubt of his honour—

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Poh! dare you proceed upon my plan?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Moſt confidently: Come to my dreſſing-room, where you'll find every thing ready for writing, and then you may explain your ſcheme more particularly.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
