sp.p: I'll attend you, but I am really ſorry, my dear, for the love of propriety, to ſee you ſo calm under the perfidy of your huſband; you ſhould be quite wretched—indeed you ſhould. Ex.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: The hell-hounds are after me.
sp.stage: Enter Connolly, at the oppoſite ſide.
sp.p: Fly, open the chambers this moment, the bailiffs are in ſight.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith and that I will; but it will be of no uſe to fly a ſtep, if I hav'n't the key.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Zounds! did not you lock the door?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Yes; but I believe I left the key on the inſide: However, I ſee no more than three people, and think we could beat them to their hearts content in three minutes.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What! and fly in the face of the law?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: To be ſure you have a great regard for the law, when you are going to fight a duel!

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: S'death! is this a time to talk? Stay here, and throw every poſſible impediment in the way of theſe execrable raſcals. (going.)

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Holloa! honey, come back: Theſe execrable raſcals are very worthy people, I fancy, for they are quietly turning down the next court.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Their appearance alarm'd me beyond meaſure.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O you ſhou'dn't judge by outſide ſhew, my dear; for there is no being a complete rogue, without the appearance of an honeſt man

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Circumſtanced as I am at preſent, every thing terrifies me; for ſhould I be arreſted, the conſequence would poſſibly be fatal, both to my honour and my love.—Belville would proclaim me publicly a coward; and Emily ſet me down as a baſe, a mercenary adventurer, who was ſolely attracted by her fortune.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why faith, honey, like yourſelf, they might be apt to judge by appearances.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: O, Connolly, a man of ſpirit ſhould learn prudence from his very pride, and conſider every unneceſſary debt he contracts as a wanton diminution of his character! the moment he makes another his creditor—he makes himſelf a ſlave! He runs the hazard of inſults, which he never can reſent, and of diſgraces which are ſeldom to be mitigated! He incurs the danger of being dragg'd, like the vileſt felon to the felon's priſon! and, ſuch is the depravity of the world, that guilt is even more likely to meet with advocates, than misfortune! Exit Leeſon.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p:
Muſha, long life to you, ould Shillala!—I wiſh I had any thing beſides my carcaſe to venture for you, for that's nothing; yet you are as welcome to it as the flowers in May. Poor lad! I don't wonder that he is ſo much afraid of a priſon, for to be ſure it is a bleſſed place to live in; and a bleſſed law it muſt be, which coops a man up from every chance of getting money, by way of making him pay his debts—But now let my thick ſkull conſider, if there is any method of preventing this infernal duel. Suppoſe I have him
bound over to the pace! No, that will never do—it would be a ſhameful thing for a gintleman to keep the pace! Beſides, I muſt appear in the buſineſs, and people may think, from my connexion with him, that he has not honour enough to throw away his life: Suppoſe I go another way to work, and ſend an anonymous letter about the affair to Mrs. Belville: They ſay, though ſhe is a woman of faſhion, that no creter upon earth can be fonder of her huſband. Surely the good genius of Ireland put this ſcheme into my head—I'll about it this minute; and if there's only one of them kept from the field, I don't think that the other can be much hurt, when there will be no body to fight with him. Exit.

div.stage: SCENE, changes to Capt. SAVAGE's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Why, faith, Belville, your detection, and ſo ſpeedily too, after all the pretended ſanctity of the morning, muſt have thrown you into a moſt humiliating ſituation.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Into the moſt diſtreſſing you can imagine: had my wife rav'd at my falſehood, in the cuſtomary manner, I cou'd have brazen'd it but pretty tollerably; but the angel-like ſweetneſs, with which ſhe bore the mortifying diſcovery, planted daggers in my boſom, and made me at that time wiſh her the verieſt vixen in the whole creation.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Yet, the ſuffering forbearance of a wife, is a quality for which ſhe is ſeldom allow'd her merit; we think it her duty to put up with our falſehood, and imagine ourſelves exceedingly generous in the main, if we practiſe no other method of breaking her heart.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Monſtrous! monſtrous! from this moment
I bid an everlaſting adieu to my vices: the generoſity of my dear girl—

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Here's a letter, Sir, which Mr. Spruce has brought you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Give me leave, Savage.—Zounds! what an induſtrious devil the father of darkneſs is, when the moment a man determines upon a good action, he ſends ſuch a thing as this, to ſtagger his reſolution.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What have you got there?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You ſhall know preſently. Will you let Spruce come in.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Where have you acquir'd all this ceremony?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Bid Spruce come in.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Is that another challenge?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: 'Tis upon my ſoul, but it came from a beautiful enemy, and dares me to give a meeting to Miſs Walſingham.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Pray, Spruce, who gave you this letter?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Miſs Walſingham's woman, Sir: ſhe ſaid it was about very particular buſineſs, and therefore I wou'dn't truſt it by any of the footmen.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, damn your diligence. aſide.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You may go home, Spruce.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: (Looking ſignificantly at his Maſter.) Is there no anſwer neceſſary, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I ſhall call at home myſelf, and give the neceſſary anſwer.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: (Aſide.) What can be the matter with him all of a ſudden, that he is ſo cold upon the ſcent of wickedneſs? Exit.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And what anſwer do you propoſe making to it, Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Read the letter, and then tell me what I ſhou'd do.—You know Miſs Walſingham's hand.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, perfectly!—This is not—yes, it is her hand!—I have too many curſt occaſions to know it.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What are you a muttering about?—Read the letter.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: If you are not entirely diſcouraged, by our laſt converſation, from renewing the ſubject which then gave offence—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Which then gave offence.—You ſee, Savage, that it is not offenſive any longer.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Sdeath! you put me out.—you may at the maſquerade, this evening—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You remember how earneſt ſhe was for the maſquerade party.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I remember it well:—and I remember, alſo, how hurt ſhe was this morning, about the affair of Miſs Leeſon. (aſide.) —have an opportunity of entertaining me—O the ſtrumpet! aſide.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But mind the cunning with which ſhe ſigns the note, for fear it ſhou'd by any accident fall into improper hands.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Ay, and you put it into very proper hands. (aſide.) I ſhall be in the blue domino.—The ſignature is— YOU KNOW WHO.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, you know who.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: May be, however, ſhe has only written this to try you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: To try me, for what purpoſe? But if you read a certain poſtcript there, I fancy you'll be of a different opinion.

p.hi: If Mr. Belville has any houſe of character to retire to, it wou'd be moſt agreeable, as there cou'd be no fear of interruption.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
What do you ſay now?—Can you recommend
me to any houſe of character, where we ſhall be free from interruption.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, curſe her houſe of character! (aſide) But ſurely, Belville, after your late determin'd reſolution to reform—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds! I forgot that.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: After the unexampled ſweetneſs of your wife's behaviour—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Don't go on, Savage: There is ſomething here (putting his hand upon his boſom) which feels already not a little aukwardly.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And can you ſtill perſiſt?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am afraid to anſwer your queſtion.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Where the plague are you flying?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: From the juſtice of your cenſure, Horace; my own is ſufficiently ſevere; yet I ſee that I ſhall be a raſcal again, in ſpite of my teeth; and good advice is only thrown away upon ſo incorrigible a libertine.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: (alone) So then this diamond of mine proves a counterfeit after all, and I am really the verieſt wretch exiſting at the moment in which I conceiv'd myſelf the peculiar favourite of fortune. O the curſed, curſed ſex! I'll ſee her once more to upbraid her with her falſehood, then acquaint my father with her perfidy, to juſtify my breaking off the marriage, and tear her from my thoughts for ever.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir! Sir! Sir!—

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, Sir,—What the devil's the matter with the booby?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Miſs Walſingham, Sir!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Ah! what of her?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Was this moment overturn'd at Mr. Belville's door, and John tells me carried in a fit into the houſe.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Ha! let me fly to her aſſiſtance. Exit.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Ha let me fly to her aſſiſtance—O, are you thereabouts. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Belville, Miſs Walſingham and Lady Rachel Mildew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: But are you indeed recover'd my dear?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Perfectly my dear,—I wasn't in the leaſt hurt, tho' greatly terrified, when the two fools of coachmen contended for the honour of being firſt, and drove the carriages together with a violence incredible.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I ſincerely rejoice at your eſcape; and now Mrs. Belville, as you promiſed to chooſe a dreſs for me if I went in your party to the maſquerade this evening, can you ſpare a quarter of an hour to Taviſtock-Street?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I am loth to leave Miſs Walſingham alone, Lady Rachel, ſo ſoon after her fright.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL
sp.p: Nay, I inſiſt that you don't ſtay at home upon my account; and Lady Rachel's company to the maſquerade is a pleaſure I have ſuch an intereſt in, that I beg you won't delay a moment to oblige her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Well, then I attend your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You are very good; and ſo is Miſs Walſingham. Exit.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I wonder Captain Savage ſtays away ſo long! where can he be all this time?—I die with impatience to tell him of my happy interview with the General.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Captain Savage, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Shew him in. [Exit Serv.] How he muſt rejoice to find his conjectures ſo fortunately realiz'd.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So, madam, you have juſt eſcap'd a ſad accident

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: And by that agreeable tone and countenance, one would almoſt imagine you were very ſorry for my eſcape.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: People, madam, who doubt the kindneſs of others, are generally conſcious of ſome defect in themſelves.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Don't madam me, with this accent of indifference. What has put you out of humour?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Are you indiſpos'd?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The Crocodile! the Crocodile! aſide.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Do you go to the maſquerade to night?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: No, but you do.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why not? come, don't be ill-natur'd, I'm not your wife yet.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nor ever will be, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: What is the meaning of this very whimſical behaviour?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The ſettled compoſure of her impudence is intolerable. (aſide.) Madam, Madam, how have I deſerv'd this uſage?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, Sir, how have I deſerved it, if you go to that?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The letter, madam!—the letter!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: What letter?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Your letter, inviting a gallant from the maſquerade to a houſe of character, madam!—What, you appear ſurpriz'd?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Well I may, at ſo ſhameleſs an aſperſion.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p:
Madam, madam, I have ſeen your letter!
Your new lover cou'dn't keep your ſecret a moment. But I have nothing to do with you,—and only come to declare my reaſons for renouncing you everlaſtingly!

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: General Savage, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Shew him up. [Exit Serv.] I am glad he is come, Sir; inform him of your reſolution to break off the match, and let there be an end of every thing between us.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The news of your accident reach'd me but this moment, madam,—or I ſhou'd have poſted much ſooner to reconnoitre your ſituation. My aid de camp, however, has not been inattentive I ſee, and I dare ſay his diligence will not be the leaſt leſſen'd, when he knows his obligations to you.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, Sir, I am perfectly ſenſible of my obligations; and the conſciouſneſs of them, was one motive of my coming here.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Then you have made your acknowledgements to miſs Wa • ſingham I hope.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: He has indeed, General, ſaid a great deal more than was neceſſary.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: That opinion proceeds from the liberality of your temper; for 'tis impoſſible he can ever ſay enough of your goodneſs.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So it is; if you knew but all, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Why who can know more of the matter than myſelf?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: This gentleman, it ſeems, has ſomething, General Savage, very neceſſary for your information.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p:
Nay, Sir, I only ſay, that for ſome particular reaſons, which I ſhall communicate to you at a
more proper time; I muſt beg leave to decline the lady whoſe hand you kindly intended for me this morning.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O you muſt!—Why then I hope you decline at the ſame time, all pretenſions to every ſhilling of my fortune. It is not in my power to make you fight, you paltroon, but I can puniſh you for cowardice.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Nay, but General, let me interpoſe here. If he can maintain any charge againſt the lady's repuation, 'twould be very hard that he ſhould be diſinherited, for a neceſſary attention to his honour.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And if I don't make the charge good, I ſubmit to be diſinherited without murmurring.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe as hell! the lady is infinitely too good for you, in every reſpect; and I undervalued her worth, when I thought of her for your wife.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I am ſure the lady is much oblig'd to your favourable opinion, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, Madam; I only do her common juſtice.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I cannot bear that you ſhou'd be diſpleas'd a moment, Sir; ſuffer me therefore to render the converſation leſs equivocable, and a few words will explain every thing.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'll hear no explanation; ar'n't my orders that you ſhou'd marry?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: For my ſake hear him, General Savage.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Madam, I diſdain every favour that is to be procur'd by your interpoſition. Exit.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: This matter muſt not be ſuffer'd to proceed farther tho', provokingly, cruelly as the Captain has behav'd. aſide.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What's that you ſay, my bewitching girl?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I ſay that you muſt make it up with the Captain, and the beſt way will be to hear his charge patiently.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am ſhock'd at the brutality of the dog; he has no more principle than a ſuttler, and no more ſteadineſs than a young recruit upon drill. But, you ſhall have ample ſatisfaction:—this very day I'll cut him off from a poſſibility of ſucceeding to a ſhilling of my fortune. He ſhall be as miſerable as—

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Dear General, do you think that this wou'd give me any ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How he became acquainted with my deſign I know not, but I ſee plainly, that his mutiny proceeds from his averſion to my marrying again.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: To your marrying again, Sir! why ſhou'd he object to that?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Why, for fear I ſhould have other children, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, it was not from that motive; and, if I can overlook his folly, you may be prevail'd upon to forgive it.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: After what you have ſeen, juſtice ſhou'd make you a little more attentive to your own intereſt, my lovely girl.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: What at the expence of his?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: In the approaching change of your ſituation, there may be a family of your own.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Suppoſe there ſhou'd, Sir; won't there be a family of his too?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I care not what becomes of his family.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: But, pray let me think a little about it, General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: 'Tis hard, indeed, when I was ſo deſirous of promoting his happineſs, that he ſhould throw any thing in the way of mine.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Recollect, Sir, his offence was wholly confin'd to me.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well, my love, and isn't it throwing an obſtacle in the way of my happineſs, when he abuſes you ſo groſly for your readineſs to marry me?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I ſee, with all your good nature, that this is a queſtion you cannot rally againſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: It is indeed, Sir.—What will become of me? aſide.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You ſeem ſuddenly diſordered, my love?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why really, Sir, this affair affects me ſtrongly.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well, it is poſſible, that for your ſake, I may not puniſh him with as much ſeverity as I intended: In about an hour I ſhall beg leave to beat up your quarters again, with Mr. Torrington; for 'tis neceſſary I ſhould ſhew you ſome proof of my gratitude, ſince you have been ſo kindly pleas'd to honour me with a proof of your affection.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: (aſide.) So, now indeed, we're in a hopeful ſituation. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Belville, and Captain Savage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: DON'T argue with me, Captain Savage; but conſider that I am a wife, and pity my diſtraction.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Dear Madam, there is no occaſion to be ſo much alarm'd; Mr. Belville has very properly determin'd not to fight; he told me ſo himſelf, and ſhould have been effectually prevented, if I hadn't known his reſolution.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: There is no knowing to what extremities he may be provok'd, if he meets Mr. Leeſon; I have ſent for you, therefore, to beg that you will ſave him from the poſſibility, either of expoſing himſelf to any danger, or of doing an injury to his adverſary.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What would you have me do, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Fly to Hyde park, and prevent, if yet poſſible, his meeting with Mr. Leeſon: Do it, I conjure you, if you'd ſave me from deſperation.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Though you have no reaſon whatever to be apprehenſive for his ſafety, Madam, yet, ſince you are ſo very much affected, I'll immediately execute your commands. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Merciful heaven! where is the generoſity, where is the ſenſe, where is the ſhame of men, to find a pleaſure in purſuits, which they cannot remember without the deepeſt horror; which they cannot follow without the meaneſt fraud; and which they cannot effect, without conſequences the moſt dreadful? The ſingle word, Pleaſure, in a maſculine ſenſe, comprehends every thing that is cruel; every thing that is baſe; and every thing that is deſperate: Yet men, in other reſpects, the nobleſt of their ſpecies, make it the principal buſineſs of their lives, and do not heſitate to break in upon the peace of the happieſt families, though their own muſt be neceſſarily expos'd to deſtruction.—O Belville! Belville!—my life! my love!—The greateſt triumph which a libertine can ever experience, is too deſpicable to be envied; 'tis at beſt nothing but a victory over his own humanity; and if he is a huſband, he muſt be dead indeed, if he is not doubly tortured upon the wheel of recollection.

div.stage: Enter Miſs WALSINGHAM and Lady RACHEL MILDEW.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Belville, I am extremely unhappy to ſee you ſo diſtreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Now, I am extremely glad to ſee her ſo, for if ſhe wasn't greatly diſtreſs'd it wou'd be monſtrouſly unnatural.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O, Matilda!—my huſband! my huſband! my children! my children!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Don't weep, my dear! don't weep! pray be comforted, all may end happily. Lady Rachel, beg of her not to cry ſo.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Why, you are crying yourſelf, Miſs Walſingham; and tho' I think it out of character to encourage her tears, I can't help keeping you company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O, why is not ſome effectual method contriv'd, to prevent this horrible practice of duelling?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I'll expoſe it on the ſtage, ſince the law now a-days, kindly leaves the whole cognizance of it to the theatre.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: And yet if the laws againſt it, were as well enforced as the laws againſt deſtroying the game, perhaps it would be equally for the benefit of the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: No law will ever be effectual till the cuſtom is render'd infamous.—Wives muſt ſhriek! —mothers muſt agonize!—orphans muſt multiply! unleſs ſome bleſſed hand ſtrips the faſcinating glare from honourable murder, and bravely expoſes the idol who is worſhip'd thus in blood. While it is diſreputable to obey the laws, we cannot look for reformation:—But if the duelliſt is once baniſhed from the preſence of his ſovereign;—if he is for life excluded the confidence of his country;—if a mark of indelible diſgrace is ſtamp'd upon him, the ſword of publick juſtice will be the ſole chaſtiſer of wrongs; trifles will not be puniſh'd with death, and offences really meriting ſuch a puniſhment, will be reſerv'd for the only proper avenger, the common executioner.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I cou'dn't have expreſs'd myſelf better on the ſubject, my dear: but till ſuch a hand as you talk of is found, the beſt will fall into the error of the times.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Yes, and butcher each other like madmen, for fear their courage ſhould be ſuſpected by fools.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: No news yet from Captain Savage?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: He can't have reach'd Hyde-park yet, my dear.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Let us lead you to you chamber, my dear; you'll be better there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Matilda, I muſt be wretched any where; but I'll attend you.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Thank heav'n, I have no huſband to plunge me into ſuch a ſituation!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: And, if I thought I cou'd keep my reſolution, I'd determine this moment on living ſingle all the days of my life. Pray don't ſpare my arm, my dear. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I fancy I am rather before the time of appointment; engagements of this kind are the only ones, in which, now-a-days, people pretend, to any punctuality:—a man is allow'd half an hours law to dinner, but a thruſt through the body muſt be given within a ſecond of the clock.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Sir.—Your name I ſuppoſe is Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Your ſuppoſition is very right, Sir; and I fancy I am not much in the wrong, when I ſuppoſe your name to be Leeſon.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: It is, Sir; I am ſorry I ſhou'd keep you here a moment.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am very ſorry, Sir, you ſhou'd bring me here at all.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I regret the occaſion, be aſſured, Sir; but 'tis not now a time for talking, we muſt proceed to action.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And yet talking is all the action I ſhall proceed to, depend upon it.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir? Where are your piſtols?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where I intend they ſhall remain till my next journey into the country, very quietly over the chimney in my dreſſing room.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: You treat this matter with too much levity, Mr. Belville; take your choice of mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I'd rather take them both, if you pleaſe, for then no miſchief ſhall be done with either of them.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Sir, this trifling is adding inſult to injury; and ſhall be reſented accordingly. Didn't you come here to give me ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, every ſatisfaction in my power.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Take one of theſe piſtols then.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Leeſon, your bravery will not at all be leſſen'd by the exerciſe of a little underſtanding: If nothing leſs than my life can atone for the injury I have unconſciouſly done you, fire at me inſtantly, but don't be offended becauſe I decline to do you an additional wrong.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: S'death, Sir, do you think I come here with an intention to murder?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You come to arm the guilty againſt the innocent, Sir; and that, in my opinion, is the moſt atrocious intention of murder.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: How's this?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Look'e, Mr. Leeſon, there's your piſtol (throws it on the ground) I have already acted very wrongly with reſpect to your ſiſter, but, Sir, I have ſome character (though perhaps little enough) to maintain, and I will not do a ſtill worſe action, in raiſing my hand againſt your life.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: This hypocrital cant of cowardice, Sir, is too palpable to diſarm my reſentment; though I held you to be a man of profligate principles, I nevertheleſs conſider'd you as a man of courage; but, if you heſitate a moment longer, by heaven, I'll chaſtiſe you on the ſpot. (Draws.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I muſt defend my life; though if it did not look like timidity, I would inform you— (they fight, Leeſon is diſarmed) —Mr. Leeſon, there is your ſword again.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Strike it through my boſom, Sir;—I don't deſire to out-live this inſtant,

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
I hope, my dear Sir, that you will long live
happy—as your ſiſter, tho' to my ſhame I can claim no merit on that account, is recovered unpolluted, by her family; but let me beg that you will now ſee the folly of deciſions by the ſword, when ſucceſs is not fortunately chain'd to the ſide of juſtice: Before I leave you, receive my ſincereſt apologies for the injuries I have done you; and, be aſſured, no occurrence will ever give me greater pleaſure, than an opportunity of ſerving you, if, after what is paſt, you ſhall at any time condeſcend to uſe me as a friend. Ex.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Very well—very well—very well.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What, you have been within hearing, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: You may ſay that.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And isn't this very fine?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why I can't ſay much as to the finery of it, Sir, but it is certainly very fooliſh.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And ſo this is my ſatisfaction after all!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Yes, and pretty ſatisfaction it is. When Mr. Belville did you but one injury, he was the greateſt villain in the world; but now that he has done you two, in drawing his ſword upon you, I ſuppoſe he is a very worthy gentleman

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: To be foil'd, baffled, diſappointed in my revenge!—What tho' my ſiſter is by accident unſtain'd, his intentions are as criminal, as if her ruin was actually perpetrated; there is no poſſibility of enduring the reflection!—I wiſh not for the blood of my enemy, but I would at leaſt have the credit of giving him life.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Arrah, my dear, if you had any regard for the life of your enemy, you ſhou'dn't put him in the way of death.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: No more of theſe reflections, my dear Connolly; my own feelings are painful enough. Will you be ſo good as to take theſe damn'd piſtols, and come with me to the coach?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p:
Troth and that I will; but don't make yourſelf
uneaſy; conſider that you have done every thing which honour required at yous hands.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I hope ſo.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why you know ſo: You have broke the laws of heaven and earth, as nobly as the firſt lord in the land, and you have convinc'd the world, that where any body has done your family one injury, you have courage enough to do it another yourſelf, by hazarding your life.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Thoſe, Connolly, who would live reputably in any country, muſt regulate their conduct in many caſes by its very prejudices.—Cuſtom, with reſpect to duelling, is a tyrant, whoſe deſpotiſm no body ventures to attack, tho' every body deteſts its cruelty.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I didn't imagine that a tyrant of any kind would be tolerated in England. But where do you think of going now? For chambers, you know, are at preſent moſt delightfully dangerous.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I ſhall go to Mrs. Crayon's.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: What the gentlewoman that paints all manner of colours in red chalk?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Yes, where I firſt became acquainted with Emily.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And where the ſweet creature has met you two or three times under pretence of ſitting for her picture.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Mrs. Crayons will, I dare ſay, oblige me in this exigency with an apartment for a few days; but come, Connolly, we have no time to loſe, tho' if you had any prudence, you would abandon me in my preſent ſituation.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, is this your opinion of my friendſhip? Do you think that any thing can ever give me half ſo much pleaſure in ſerving you, as ſeeing you ſurrounded by misfortunes. Exeunt.

div.stage: The Scene changes to an Apartment at Belville's.
Enter General Savage, Torrington, and Spruce.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Miſs Walſingham will wait on you im-immediately, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: (aſide) What can old Holifernes want ſo continually with Miſs Walſingham? Exit

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: When I bring this ſweet mild creature home, I ſhall be able to break her ſpirit to my own wiſhes— I'll inure her to proper diſcipline from the firſt moment, and make her tremble at the very thought of mutiny.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ah, General, you are wonderfully brave, when you know the meekneſs of your adverſary.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Envy, Torrington—ſtark, ſtaring envy: few fellows, on the borders of fifty, have ſo much reaſon as myſelf, to boaſt of a blooming young woman's partiality.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: On the borders of fifty, man!—beyond the confines of threeſcore.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The more reaſon I have to boaſt of my victory then; but don't grumble at my triumph, you ſhall have a kiſs of the bride, let that content you, Torrington.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your moſt obedient: General, I intended writing to you about a trifling miſtake; but poor Mrs. Belville has been ſo very ill, that I cou'dn't find an opportunity.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am very ſorry for Mrs. Belville's illneſs, but I am happy, Madam, to be perſonally in the way of receiving your commands, and I wait upon you with Mr. Torrington, to talk about a marriage ſettlement

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Heavens! how ſhall I undeceive him?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: 'Tis rather an aukward buſineſs, Miſs Walſingham, to trouble you upon; but as the General wiſhes that the affair may be as private as poſſible, he thought it better to ſpeak to yourſelf, than to treat with any other perſon.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
Yes, my lovely girl; and to convince you,
that I intend to carry on an honourable war, not to pillage like a free-booter, Mr. Torrington will be a truſtee.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I am infinitely oblig'd to your intention, but there's no neceſſity to talk about any ſettlement—for—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam,—pardon me, there is— beſides, I have determin'd that there ſhall be one, and what I once determine is abſolute.—A tolerable hint for her own behaviour, when I have married her, Torrington. aſide to Tor.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I muſt not ſhock him before Mr. Torrington (aſide). General Savage, will you give me leave to ſpeak a few words in private to you.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: There is no occaſion for ſounding a retreat, Madam; Mr. Torrington is acquainted with the whole buſineſs, and I am determin'd, for your ſake, that nothing ſhall be done without him.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I can have no objection to your hearing the lady ex parte, General.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: What I have to ſay, Sir, is of a very particular nature.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: (riſing) I'll leave the room then.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (oppoſing him) You ſhan't leave the room, Torrington. Miſs Walſingham ſhall have a ſpecimen of my command, even before marriage, and you ſhall ſee, that every woman is not to bully me out of my determination. (aſide to Tor.)

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Well, General, you muſt have your own way.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (to Tor.) Don't you ſee that it's only fighting the battle ſtoutly at firſt, with one of theſe gentle creatures?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: (ſignificantly) Ah, General!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I own, Madam, your ſituation is a diſtreſſing one; let us ſit down—let us ſit down—

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: It is unſpeakably diſtreſſing indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p:
Diſtreſſing however as it may be, we muſt proceed
to iſſue, Madam; the General propoſes your jointure to be 1000 l. a year.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: General Savage!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You think this too little, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I can't think of any jointure, Sir.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why to be ſure, a jointure it at beſt but a melancholly poſſeſſion, for it muſt be purchaſed by the loſs of the huſband you love.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Pray don't name it, Mr. Torrington.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (kiſſing her hand) A thouſand thanks to you, my lovely girl.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, let go my hand.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I ſhall be mad 'till it gives me legal poſſeſſion of the town.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Gentlemen—General—Mr. Torrington—I beg you'll hear me.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: By all means, my adorable creature; I can never have too many proofs of your diſintereſted affection.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: There is a capital miſtake in this whole affair—I am ſinking under a load of diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Your confuſion makes you look charmingly though.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: There is no occaſion to talk of jointures or marriages to me; I am not going to be married.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Nor have I an idea in nature, however enviable I think the honour, of being your wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why here's a demur!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I am afraid, Sir, that in our converſation this morning, my confuſion ariſing from the particularity of the ſubject, has led you into a material miſconception.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am thunderſtruck, madam! I cou'dn't miſtake my ground.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p:
As clear a n • l • proſ •
as ever was iſſued by an attorney general.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
Surely you can't forget, that at the firſt word you hung out a flag of truce, told me even
that I had a previous friend in the fort, and didn't ſo much as hint at a ſingle article of capitulation?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Now for the rejoinder to this replication.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: All this is unqueſtionably true, General, and perhaps a good deal more; but in reality my confuſion before you on this ſubject to day, was ſuch, that I ſcarcely knew what I ſaid; I was dying with diſtreſs, and at this moment am very little better;— permit me to retire, General Savage, and only ſuffer me to add, that tho' I think myſelf highly flatter'd by your addreſſes, it is impoſſible for me ever to receive them. Lord! Lord! I am glad its over in any manner. Ex.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why, we are a little out in this matter, General; the judge has decided againſt us, when we imagin'd ourſelves ſure of the cauſe.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The gates ſhut in my teeth, juſt as I expected the keys from the governor.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I am diſappointed myſelf, man; I ſhan't have a kiſs of the bride.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: At my time of life too!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I ſaid from the firſt you were too old for her.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Zounds to fancy myſelf ſure of her, and to triumph upon a certainty of victory.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay, and to kiſs her hand in a rapturous return for her tenderneſs to you:—let me adviſe you never to kiſs before folks, as long as you live again.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Don't diſtract me, Torrington! a joke, where a friend has the misfortune to loſe the battle, is a downright inhumanity.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: You told me that your ſon had accus'd her of ſomething that you would not hear; ſuppoſe we call at his lodgings, he perhaps, as an amicus-curiae, may be able to give us a little information.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Thank you for the thought;—But keep your finger more than ever upon you lips, dear Torrington. You know how I dread the danger of ridicule, and it wou'd be too much, not only to be thraſh'd out of the field, but to be laugh'd at into the bargain.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I thought when you made a preſentment of your ſweet perſon to Miſs Walſingham, that the bill wou'd be return'd ignoramus. Exeunt.

div.stage: Mrs. BELVILLE and Lady RACHEL MILDEW, diſcovered on a Sopha.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You heard what Captain Savage ſaid?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I would flatter myſelf, but my heart will not ſuffer it; the Park might be too full for the horrid purpoſe, and perhaps they are gone to decide the quarrel in ſome other place.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: The Captain enquir'd of numbers in the Park without hearing a ſyllable of them, and is therefore poſitive that they are parted without doing any miſchief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I am, nevertheleſs, torn by a thouſand apprehenſions, and my fancy, with a gloomy kind of fondneſs, faſtens on the moſt deadly, This very morning, I exultingly numbered myſelf in the catalogue of the happieſt wives.—Perhaps I am a wife no longer;—perhaps, my little innocents, your unhappy father is at this moment breathing his laſt ſigh, and wiſhing, O, how vainly! that he had not prefer'd a guilty pleaſure to his own life, to my eternal peace of mind, and your felicity!

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Madam! madam! my maſter! my maſter!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Is he ſafe?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My love!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O Mr. Belville! faints.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Aſſiſtance, quick!

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: There ſhe revives.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The angel-ſoftneſs! how this rends my heart?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p:
O, Mr. Belville, if you cou'd conceive
the agonies I have endur'd, you would avoid the poſſibility of another quarrel as long as you liv'd, out of common humanity.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My deareſt creature, ſpare theſe tender reproaches; you know not how ſufficiently I am puniſh'd to ſee you thus miſerable.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: That's pleaſant indeed, when you have yourſelf deliberately loaded her with affliction.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Pray, pray Lady Rachel, have a little mercy: Your poor humble ſervant has been a very naughty boy,—but if you only forgive him this ſingle time, he will never more deſerve the rod of correction.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Since you are return'd ſafe, I am happy. Excuſe theſe fooliſh tears, they guſh in ſpite of me.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: How contemptible do they render me, my love!

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Come, my dear, you muſt turn your mind from this gloomy ſubject.—Suppoſe we ſtep up ſtairs and communicate our pleaſure to Miſs Walſingham?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: With all my heart. Adieu, recreant!

div.stage: Exeunt Mrs. Bel. and Lady Rach.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I don't deſerve ſuch a woman, I don't deſerve her.—Yet, I believe I am the firſt huſband, that ever found fault with a wife, for having too much goodneſs.
What's the matter?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Your ſiſter—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What of my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Sir, is elop'd.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My ſiſter!

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: There is a letter left, Sir, in which ſhe ſays, that her motive was a diſlike to a match with Captain Savage, as ſhe has plac'd her affections unalterably on another gentleman.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Death and damnation!

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p:
Mrs. Moreland, your mother, is in the greateſt diſtreſs, Sir, and begs you will immediately
go with the ſervant that brought the meſſage; for he obſerving the young lady's maid carrying ſome bundles out, a little ſuſpiciouſly, thought there muſt be ſome ſcheme going on, and dogg'd a hackney coach, in which Miſs Morland went off, to the very houſe where it ſet her down.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Bring me to the ſervant, inſtantly;—but don't let a ſyllable of this matter reach my wife's ears, her ſpirits are already too much agitated. Exit.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Zounds! we ſhall be paid home, for the tricks we have play'd in other families. Exit.

div.stage: Scene changes to Capt. SAVAGE's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The vehemence of my reſentment againſt this abandon'd woman has certainly led me too far. I ſhou'dn't have acquainted her with my diſcovery of her b • ſeneſs;—no, if I had acted properly, I ſhould have conceal'd all knowledge of the tranſaction 'till the very moment of her guilt, and then burſt upon her when ſhe was ſolacing with her paramour, in all the fulneſs of ſecurity. Now, if ſhe ſhould either alter her mind, with reſpect to going to the maſquerade, or go in a different habit to elude my obſervation, I not only 〈◊〉 the opportunity of expoſing her, but give her time to plan ſome plauſible excuſe for her infamous letter to Belville.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: General Savage, and Mr. Torrington, Sir.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: You blockhead, why did you let them wait a moment? What can be the meaning of this viſit?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I come, Horace, to talk to you about Miſs Walſingham.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: She's the moſt worthleſs woman exiſting, Sir: I can convince you of it.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I have already chang'd my own opinion of her.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What you have found her out yourſelf, Sir?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Yes, he has made a trifling diſcovery.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
S'death, don't make me contemptible to my ſon.
aſide to TOR.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: But, Sir, what inſtance of her precious behaviour has come to your knowledge? For an hour has ſcarcely elapſed, ſince you thought her a miracle of goodneſs

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay, he has thought her a miracle of goodneſs, within this quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Why ſhe has a manner that wou'd impoſe upon all the world.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Yes, but ſhe has a manner alſo to undeceive the world thoroughly.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: That we have found pretty recently; however, in this land of liberty, none are to be pronounced guilty, 'till they are poſitively convicted; I can't therefore find againſt Miſs Walſingham, upon the bare ſtrength of preſumptive evidence.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Preſumptive evidence! hav'n't I promis'd you ocular demonſtration?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay, but 'till we receive this demonſtration, my good friend, we cannot give judgement.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Then I'll tell you at once, who is the object of her honourable affections.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Who— who—

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What would you think if they were plac'd on Belville?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Upon Belville! has ſhe deſerted to him from the corps of virtue?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe wrote to him, deſiring to be taken from the maſquerade to ſome convenient ſcene of privacy, and tho' I have ſeen the letter, ſhe has the impudence to deny her own hand.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What a fiend is there then diſguis'd under the 〈◊〉 of an angel!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: The delicate creature that was dying with confuſion!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Only come with me to the maſquerade, and you ſhall ſee Belville carry her off: 'Twas about the ſcandalous appointment with him, I was ſpeaking, when you conceiv'd I treated her ſo rudely.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And you were only anxious to ſhew her in her real character to me, when I was ſo exceedingly offended with you.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nothing elſe in the world, Sir; I knew you would deſpiſe and deteſt her, the moment you were acquainted with her baſeneſs.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How ſhe brazen'd it out before my face, and what a regard ſhe affected for your intereſt! I was a madman not to liſten then to your explanation.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Tho' you both talk this point well, I ſtill ſee nothing but ſtrong preſumption againſt Miſs Walſingham: Miſtakes have already happened, miſtakes may happen again; and I will not give up a lady's honour, upon an evidence that wou'd not caſt a common pickpocket at the Old Baily.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Come to the maſquerade then and be convinc'd.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Let us detach a party for dreſſes immediately. Yet remember, Torrington, that the punctuality of evidence which is neceſſary in a court of law, is by no means requiſite in a court of honour.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Perhaps it would be more to the honour of your honourable courts if it was. Exeunt.

div.stage: The Scene changes to an Apartment at Mrs. Crayon's,

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (behind.) My dear, you muſt excuſe me.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you muſt not go up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Indeed but I will; the man is poſitive to the houſe, and I • ll ſearch every room in it, from the cellar to the garret, if I don't find the lady. James, don't ſtir from the ſtreet door.

div.stage: Enter Belville followed by a Maid.

sp.speaker: MAID
sp.p:
Sir, you are the ſtrangeſt gentleman I ever
met with in all my born days:—I wiſh my miſtreſs was at home.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am a ſtrange fellow, my dear—But if your miſtreſs was at home, I ſhou'd take the liberty of peeping into the apartments.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: Sir, there's company in that room, you can't go in there.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Now that's the very reaſon I will go in.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: This muſt be ſome great man, or he wou'dn't behave ſo obſtropolous.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Good manners by your leave a little. (forcing the door.) Whoever my gentleman is, I'll call him to a ſevere reckoning:—I have been juſt call'd to one myſelf, for making free with another man's ſiſter.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Who is it that dares commit an outrage upon this apartment?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: An Engliſhman's very lodging; ay, and an Iriſhman's too, I hope, is his caſtle;—an Iriſhman is an Engliſhman all the world over.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Mr. Leeſon!

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: O we ſhall have murder. running off.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Run into that room, my dear, and ſtay with the young lady, Exit Maid.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And Connolly let nobody elſe into that room.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Let me alone for that, honey, if this gentleman has fifty people.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Whence is it, Mr. Belville, that you perſecute me thus with injuries?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am fill'd with aſtoniſhment!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, to ſpeak the truth, you do look a little ſurpriz'd.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Anſwer me, Sir; what is the foundation of this new violence?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am come, Mr. Leeſon, upon an affair, Sir—

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: The devil burn me if he was half ſo much confounded a while ago, when there was a naked ſword at his breaſt.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am come, Mr. Leeſon, upon an affair, Sir, that—How the devil ſhall I open it to him, ſince the tables are ſo fairly turn'd upon me.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Diſpatch, Sir, for I have company in the next room.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: A lady, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Suppoſe it is, Sir?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And the lady's name is Moreland, isn't it, Sir?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I can't ſee what buſineſs you have with her name, Sir, You took away my ſiſter, and I hope you have no deſigns upon the lady in the next room.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Indeed but I have.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: The devil you have!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Well, this is the moſt unaccountable man I ever heard of, he'll have all the women in the town, I believe.

sp.speaker: LEES,
sp.p: And pray, Sir, what pretenſions, have you to the lady in the next room, even ſuppoſing her to be Miſs Moreland?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No other pretenſions than what a brother ſhould have to the defence of his ſiſter's honour: You thought yourſelf authoriſed to cut my throat a-while ago in a ſimilar buſineſs.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And is Miſs Moreland your ſiſter?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir, there is inſolence in that queſtion; you know ſhe is.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: By heaven, I did not know it till this moment; but I rejoice at the diſcovery: This is blow for blow!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Devil burn me but they have fairly made a ſwop of it.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And you really didn't know that Miſs Moreland was my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p:
I don't conceive myſelf under much neceſſity of apologizing to you, Sir; but I am incapable of a diſhonourable deſign upon any woman; and tho' Miſs Moreland in our ſhort acquaintance, repeatedly
mentioned her brother, ſhe never once told me that his name was Belville.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And he has had ſuch few opportunities of being in her company, unleſs by letters, honey, that he knew nothing more of her connections, than her being a ſweet pretty creter, and having 30,000 l.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The fortune, I dare ſay, no way leſſened the force of her attractions.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I am above diſſimulation—It really did not.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Leeſon, our families have ſhewn ſuch a very ſtrong inclination to come together, that it would really be a pity to diſappoint them.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul and ſo it would; though the dread of being forc'd to have a huſband, the young lady tells us, quicken'd her reſolution to marry this gentleman.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O ſhe had no violence of that kind to apprehend from her family; therefore, Mr. Leeſon, ſince you ſeem as neceſſary for the girl's happineſs, as ſhe ſeems for your's, you ſhall marry her here in town, with the conſent of all her friends, and ſave yourſelf the trouble of an expedition to Scotland.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Can I believe you ſerious?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds, Leeſon, that air of ſurpriſe is a ſad reproach! I didn't ſurpriſe you when I did a bad action, but I raiſe your aſtoniſhment, when I do a good one.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And by my ſoul, Mr. Belville, if you knew how a good action becomes a man, you'd never do a bad one as long as you liv'd.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: You have given me life and happineſs in one day, Mr. Belville! however, it is now time you ſhould ſee your ſiſter; I know you'll be gentle with her, tho' you have ſo much reaſon to condemn her choice, and generouſly remember that her elopement proceeded from the great improbability there was of a beggar's ever meeting with the approbation of her family.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Don't apologize for your circumſtances, Leeſon; a princeſs could do no more than make you happy, and if you make her ſo, you meet her upon terms of the moſt perfect equality.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: This is a new way of thinking, Mr. Belville.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: 'Tis only an honeſt way of thinking, and I conſider my ſiſter a gainer upon the occaſion; for a man of your merit is more difficult to be found, than a woman of her fortune. Exeunt Leeſon and Belville.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: What's the reaſon now that I can't ſkip, and laugh, and rejoice, at this affair? Upon my ſoul my heart's as full as if I had met with ſome great misfortune. Well, pleaſure in the extreme is certainly a very painful thing: I am really aſham'd of theſe womans drops, and yet I don't know but that I ought to bluſh for being aſham'd of them, for I am ſure nobody's eye ever looks half ſo well, as when it is diſfigured by a tear of humanity. Exit.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
WELL, happineſs is once more mine, and the women are all going in tip-top ſpirits to the maſquerade. Now, Mr. Belville, let me have a few words with you; Miſs Walſingham, the ripe, the luxurious Miſs Walſingham, expects to find you there burning with impatience:—But, my dear friend, after the occurrences of the day, can you be weak enough to plunge into freſh crimes? Can you be baſe
enough to abuſe the goodneſs of that angel your wife; and wicked enough, not only to deſtroy the innocence which is ſhelter'd beneath your own roof, but to expoſe your family perhaps again, to the danger of loſing a ſon, a brother, a father, and a huſband? The poſſeſſion of the three Graces is ſurely too poor a recompence for the folly you muſt commit, for the ſhame you muſt feel, and the conſequences you muſt hazard. Upon my ſoul if I ſtruggle a little longer, I ſhall riſe in my own opinion, and be leſs a raſcal than I think myſelf:—Ay, but the object is bewitching;—the matter will be an eternal ſecret—and if it is known that I ſneak in this pitiful manner from a fine woman, when the whole elyſium of her perſon ſolicits me:—well, and am I afraid the world ſhould know that I have ſhrunk from an infamous action?—A thouſand bleſſings on you dear conſcience for that one argument;—I ſhall be an honeſt man after all—Suppoſe, however, that I give her the meeting; that's dangerous;—that's dangerous:—and I am ſo little accuſtomed to do what is right, that I ſhall certainly do what is wrong, the moment I am in the way of temptation. Come, Belville, your reſolution is not ſo very ſlender a dependance, and you owe Miſs Walſingham reparation for the injury which you have done her principles. I'll give her the meeting—I'll take her to the houſe I intended—I'll—Zounds! what a fool I have been all this time, to look for precarious ſatisfaction in vice, when there is ſuch exquiſite pleaſure to be found at a certainty in virtue! Exit

div.stage: Enter Lady Rachel and Mrs Belville.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: For mirth ſake don't let him ſee us: There has been a warm debate between his paſſion and his conſcience.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL
sp.p: And the latter is the conqueror, my life for it.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Belville you are the beſt of women, and ought to have the beſt of huſbands.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I have the beſt of huſbands.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I have not time to diſpute the matter with you now; but I ſhall put you into my comedy to teach wives, that the beſt receipt for matrimonial happineſs, is to be deaf, dumb, and blind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Poh! poh! you are a ſatireſt, Lady Rachel—But we are loſing time; ſhou'dn't we put on our dreſſes, and prepare for the grand ſcene?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Don't you tremble at the trial?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, I am ſure my heart has no occaſion.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Have you let Miſs Walſingham into our little plot?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: You know ſhe cou'd not be inſenſible of Mr. Belville's deſign upon herſelf, and it is no farther than that deſign, we have any thing to carry into execution.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Well, ſhe may ſerve to facilitate the matter, and therefore I am not ſorry that you have truſted her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: We ſhall be too late, and then what ſignifies all your fine plotting.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Is it not a little pang of jealouſy that wou'd fain now quicken our motions?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: No, Lady Rachel, it is a certainty of my huſband's love and generoſity, that makes me wiſh to come to the trial. I wou'd not exchange my confidence in his affections for all the mines of Peru; ſo nothing you can ſay will make me miſerable.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You are a moſt unaccountable woman; ſo away with you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Why, Ghaſtly, the old general your maſter is a greater fool than I ever thought he was: He want to marry Miſs Walſingham?

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p:
Mrs. Tempeſt ſuſpected that there was
ſomething going forward, by all his hugger-mugger conſulting with Mr. Torrington; and ſo ſet me on to liſten.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: She's a good friend of your's, and that thing ſhe made the General give you the other day in the hoſpital, is I ſuppoſe a ſnug hundred a year.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: Better than two; I waſh for near four thouſand people: there was a major of horſe who put in for it, and pleaded a large family—

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: With long ſervices, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: Yes, but Mrs. Tempeſt inſiſted upon my long ſervices; ſo the major was ſet aſide—However to keep the thing from the damn'd News-papers, I fancy he will ſucceed the barber, who died laſt night, poor woman, of a lying-in fever, after being brought to bed of three children,—Places in public inſtitutions.—

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Are often ſweetly diſpos'd I think of aſking Belville for ſomething, one of theſe days.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: He has great intereſt.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: I might be a juſtice of peace; if I pleaſed, and in a ſhabby neighbourhood, where the mere ſwearing would bring in ſomething tolerable; but there are ſo many ſtrange people let into the commiſſion now-a-days, that I ſhou'dn't like to have my name in the liſt.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: No, no, I leave that to paltry tradeſmen, and ſhall think of ſome little ſinecure, or a ſmall penſion on the Iriſh eſtabliſhment.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: Well, ſucceſs attend you. I muſt hobble home as faſt as I can, to know if Mrs. Tempeſt has any orders. O, there's a rare ſtorm brewing for our old goat of a General.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: When ſhall we crack a bottle together?

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p:
O, I ſhan't touch a glaſs of Claret theſe three weeks; for laſt night I gave nature a little fillip with a drunken bout, according to the doctor's directions; I have entirely left off bread, and I am in great hopes that I ſhall get rid of my gout by theſe means,
ſpecially if I can learn to eat my meat quite raw like a cannibal.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: Look at me, Spruce, I was once as likely a young fellow as any under ground in the whole pariſh of St. James's:—but waiting on the General ſo many years.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Ay, and following his example, Ghaſtly.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: 'Tis too true: has reduc'd me to what you ſee. Theſe miſerable ſpindles wou'd do very well for a lord or a duke, Spruce; but they are a ſad diſgrace to a poor valet de chambre. Exit.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Well, I don't believe there's a gentleman's gentleman within the weekly bills, who joins a prudent ſolicitude for the main-chance, to a ſtrict care of his conſtitution, better than myſelf. I have a little girl who ſtands me in about three guineas a week; I never bet more than a pound upon a rubber of whiſt; I always ſleep with my head very warm; and ſwallow a new laid egg every morning with my chocolate. Exit.

div.stage: The Scene changes to the Street, two Chairs croſs the Stage, knock at a Door, and ſet down BELVILLE and a Lady.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This way, my dear creature! Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Gen. Savage, Capt. Savage, and Torrington.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: There! there they go in:—You ſee the place is quite convenient, not twenty yards from the maſquerade.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How cloſely the fellow ſticks to her.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Like the great ſeal to the peerage patent of a chancellor. But, gentlemen, we have ſtill no more than proof preſumptive:—where is the ocular demonſtration which we were to have?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I'll ſwear to the blue domino; 'tis a very remarkable one, and ſo is Belville's.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p:
You wou'd have rare cuſtom among the New-gate
ſollicitors, if you'd venture an oath upon the identity of the party under it.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: 'Tis the very ſize and ſhape of Miſs Walſingham.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And yet I have a ſtrange notion that there is a trifling alibi in this caſe.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: It wou'd be a damn'd affair if we ſhou'd be countermin'd.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, follow me, here's the door left luckily open, and I'll ſoon clear up the matter beyond a queſtion. Enters the houſe.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why your ſon is mad, General. This muſt produce a deadly breach with Belville. For heav'n's ſake, let's go in and prevent any exceſſes of his raſhneſs.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: By all means, or the poor fellow's generous anxiety on my account may be productive of very fatal conſequences. Exeunt.

div.stage: The Scene changes to an aparment, Belville unmaſked, and a lady in a blue domino maſk'd.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My dear Miſs Walſingham, we are now perfectly ſafe, yet I will by no means intreat you to unmaſk, becauſe I am convinc'd, from the propriety with which you repuls'd my addreſſes this morning, that you intend the preſent interview ſhould make me ſtill more deeply ſenſible of my preſumption.—I never lied ſo aukwardly in all my life; if it was to make her comply, I ſhould be at no loſs for language. (aſide) The ſituation in which I muſt appear before you, Madam, is certainly a very humiliating one; but I am perſuaded that your generoſity will be gratified to hear, that I have bid an everlaſting adieu to my profligacy, and am now only alive to the virtues of Mrs. Belville.—She won't ſpeak—I don't wonder at it, for brazen as I am myſelf, if I met ſo mortifying a rejection, I ſhould be curſedly out of countenance.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: (behind) I will go in.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (behind.) I command you to deſiſt.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: (behind.) This will be an affair for the Old-Bailey.

div.stage: The noiſe grows more violent, and continues.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, what the devil is all this?—Don't be alarm'd, Miſs Walſingham, be aſſur'd I'll protect you at the hazard of my life;—ſtep into this cloſet,— you ſhan't be diſcover'd depend upon it; (ſhe goes in): And now to find out the cauſe of this confuſion. unlocks the door.

div.stage: Enter Gen. Savage, Capt. Savage, and Torrington.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Savage! what is the meaning of this ſtrange behaviour?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Where is Miſs Walſingham?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: So then, Sir, this is a premeditated ſcheme, for which I am oblig'd to your friendſhip.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Where's Miſs Walſingham, Sir?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Dear Belville, he is out of his ſenſes; this ſtorm was entirely againſt my orders.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: If he proceeds much longer in theſe vagaries, we muſt amuſe him with a commiſſion of lunacy.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This is neither a time nor a place for argument, Mr. Torrington; but as you and the General ſeem to be in the poſſeſſion of your ſenſes, I ſhall be glad if you'll take this very friendly gentleman away; and depend upon it, I ſhan't die in his debt for the preſent obligation.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And depend upon it, Sir, pay the obligation when you will, I ſhan't ſtir 'till I ſee Miſs Walſingham.—Look'ee, Belville, there are ſecret reaſons for my behaving in this manner; reaſons, which you yourſelf will approve, when you know them;—my father here—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Diſavows your conduct in every particular, and would rejoice to ſee you at the halberds.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And, for my part, I told him previouſly 'twas a downright burglary.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, let your different motives for breaking in upon me in this agreeable manner, be what they may, I don't ſee that I am leſs annoy'd by my friends than my enemy. I muſt therefore again, requeſt that you will all walk down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I'll firſt walk into this room.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Really, I think you will not.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What phrenzy poſſeſſes the fellow to urge this matter farther?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
BEL.
sp.p: Then you muſt make your way thro' me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: There, I knew ſhe was in the room:— there's the blue domino.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Put up your ſword, if you don't deſire to be caſhier'd from my favour for ever.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, wou'd you come out, madam? But, you have nothing to apprehend.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Pray, madam, will you have the goodneſs to unmaſk?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She ſhan't unmaſk.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I ſay ſhe ſhall.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I ſay ſhe ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Pray, let me oblige the gentleman?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Death and deſtruction, here's a diſcovery!

sp.speaker: GEN. and TOR.
sp.p: Mrs. Belville!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Belville, gentlemen: Is conſugal fidelity ſo very terrible a thing now a-days, that a man is to ſuffer death for being found in company with his own wife?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My love, this is a ſurprize, indeed—But it is a moſt agreeable one; ſince you find me really aſham'd of my former follies, and cannot now doubt the ſincerity of my reformation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I am too happy! this ſingle moment wou'd over pay a whole life of anxiety.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where ſhall I attend you? Will you return to the maſquerade?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O no! Lady Rachel and Miſs Walſingham are by this time at our houſe, with Mr. Leeſon and the Iriſh gentleman whom you preſs'd into our party, impatiently expecting the reſult of this adventure.

sp.speaker: BEL.
Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: And when you next diſturb a téte a téte, for pity to a poor wife, don't let it be ſo very uncuſtomary a party, as the matrimonial one.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (to the Capt.) So, Sir, you have led us upon a bleſſed expedition here.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Now, don't you think that if your courts of honour, like our courts of law, ſearch'd a little minutely into evidence, it wou'd be equally to the credit of their underſtandings?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Tho' I am cover'd with confuſion at my miſtake (for you ſee, Belville was miſtaken as well as myſelf,) I am overjoy'd at this diſcovery of Miſs Walſingham's innocence.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I ſhou'd exult in it too, with a feu de joy, if it didn't now ſhew the impoſſibility of her ever being Mrs. Savage.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Dear Sir, why ſhould you think that an impoſſibility? Tho' ſome miſtake • s have occurr'd conſequence I ſuppoſe, of Mrs. Belville's little plot upon her huſband, I dare ſay Miſs Walſingham may yet be prevail'd upon to come into our family.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Take care of a new error in your proceedings, young gentleman.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Ay, another defeat would make us compleatly deſpicable.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Sir, I'll forſeit my life, if ſhe does not conſent to the marriage this very night.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Only bring this matter to bear, and I'll forgive you every thing.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: The Captain ſhou'd be inform'd, I think General, that ſhe declin'd it peremptorily this evening.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Ay, do you hear that, Horace?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am not at all ſurpriz'd at it, conſidering the general miſconception we labour'd under. But I'll immediately to Belville's, explain the whole myſtery, and conclude every thing to your ſatisfaction. Exit.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: So, Torrington, we ſhall be able to take the field again, you ſee.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: But how in the name of wonder has your ſon found out your intention of marrying Miſs Walſingham? I look'd upon myſelf as the only perſon acquainted with the ſecret.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: That thought has march'd itſelf two or three times to my own recollection. For tho' I gave him ſome diſtant hints of the affair, I took particular care to keep behind the works of a proper circumſpection.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: O, if you gave him any hints at all, I am not ſurpriz'd at his diſcovering every thing.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I ſhall be all impatience 'till I hear of his interview with Miſs Walſingham: Suppoſe my dear friend we went to Belville's, 'tis but in the next ſtreet, and we ſhall be there in the lighting of a match.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Really this is a pretty buſineſs for a man of my age and profeſſion, trot here, trot there. But, as I have been weak enough to make myſelf a kind of party in the cauſe, I own that I have curioſity enough to be anxious about the determination.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Come along my old boy; and remember the ſong, "Servile ſpirits, &c." Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Captain Savage and Miſs Walſingham.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nay, but my deareſt Miſs Walſingham, the extenuation of my own conduct to Belville made it abſolutely neceſſary for me to diſcover my engagements with you; and as happineſs is now ſo fortunately in our reach, I flatter myſelf you will be prevail'd upon to forgive an error, which proceeded only from an extravagance of love.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: To think me capable of ſuch an action, Captain Savage! I am terrified at the idea of a union with you, and it is better for a woman at any time, to ſacrifice an inſolent lover, than to accept of a ſuſpicious huſband.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: In the happieſt unions, my deareſt creature, there muſt be always ſomething to overlook on both ſides.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Very civil, truly.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Pardon me, my life, for this frankneſs; and recollect, that if the lover has thro' miſconception been unhappily guilty, he brings a huſband altogether reform'd to your hands.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Well, I ſee I muſt forgive you at laſt, ſo I may as well make a merit of neceſſity, you provoking creature.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And may I hope, indeed, for the bleſſing of this hand?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Why, you wretch, would you have me force it upon you? I think, after what I have ſaid, a ſoldier might have ventur'd to take it without farther ceremony.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Angelic creature! thus I ſeize it as my lawful prize.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Well, but now you have obtained this ineſtimable prize, Captain, give me again leave to aſk if you have had a certain explanation with the General?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: How can you doubt it?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: And he is really impatient for our marriage?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: 'Tis incredible how earneſt he is.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: What, did he tell you of his Interview with me this evening, when he brought Mr. Torrington?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: O, then, I can have do doubt.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: If a ſhadow of doubt remains, here he comes to remove it. Joy, my dear Sir! joy a thouſand times!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What, my dear boy, have you carried the day?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I have been weak enough to indulge him with a victory, indeed, General.

p.hi: None but the brave, none but the brave, &c.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I congratulate you heartily on this decree, General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: This had nearly proved a day of diſappointment, but the ſtars have fortunately turn'd it in my favour, and now I reap the rich reward of my victory. (Salutes her)

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And here I take her from you, as the greateſt good which heav'n can ſend me.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: O, Captain!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You take her as the greateſt good which heav'n can ſend you, ſirrah; I take her as the greateſt good which heav'n can ſend me: And now what have you to ſay to her?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: General Savage!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Here will be a freſh injunction to ſtop proceedings.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Are we never to have done with miſtakes?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What miſtakes can have happen'd now my ſweeteſt? you deliver'd up your dear hand to me this moment?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: True, Sir; but I thought you were going to beſtow my dear hand upon this dear gentleman.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How! that dear gentleman!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am thunder-ſtruck!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: General—None but the brave, &c. ſings.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: So the covert way is clear'd at laſt; and you have imagin'd that I was all along negociating for this fellow, when I was gravely ſoliciting for myſelf?

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: No other idea, Sir, ever once enter'd my imagination.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: General.—Noble minds ſhould ne'er deſpair, &c. ſings.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Zounds! here's all the company pouring upon us in full gallop, and I ſhall be the laughing ſtock of the whole town.

div.stage: Enter Belville, Mrs. Belville, Lady Rachel, Leeſon and Connolly.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, General, we have left you a long time together. Shall I give you joy?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: No; wiſh me demoliſh'd in the fortifications of Dunkirk.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: The General appears diſconcerted.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: The gentleman looks as if he had fought a hard battle.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Ay, and gain'd nothing but a defeat, my dear.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I'll ſhew cauſe for his behaviour.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Death and damnation! not for the world. I am taken by ſurpriſe here; let me conſider a moment how to cut my way thro' the enemy.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: How cou'd you be deceiv'd in this manner. To Capt.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: O, Mr. Torrington, we are much oblig'd to you; you have been in town ever ſince laſt night, and only ſee us now by accident.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I have been very buſy, Madam; but you look ſadly, very ſadly indeed! your old diſorder the jaundice, I ſuppoſe, has been very troubleſome to you?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Sir, you have a very extraordinary mode of complimenting your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I don't believe for all that, that there's a word of a lie in the truth he ſpeaks. aſide

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Miſs Walſingham, Capt. Savage has been telling Mr. Belville and me of a very extraordinary miſtake.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: 'Tis very ſtrange indeed, miſtake on miſtake.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: 'Tis no way ſtrange to find every body properly ſtruck with the merit of Miſs Walſingham.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: A compliment from you now, Mr. Belville, is really worth accepting.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: If I thought the affair cou'd be kept a ſecret, by making the town over to my ſon, ſince I am utterly ſhut out myſelf—

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: He ſeems exceedingly embarraſſed.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: If I thought that;—why mortified as I muſt be in giving it up, I think I cou'd reſolve upon the manoeuvre, to ſave myſelf from univerſal ridicule: but it can't be;—it can't be; and I only double my own diſappointment in rewarding the diſobedience of the raſcal who has ſupplanted me. There!—there! they are all talking of it, all laughing at me, and I ſhall run mad!

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: (behind) I ſay, you feather-headed puppy, he is in this houſe; my own ſervant ſaw him come in, and I will not ſtir 'till I find him.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: She here!—then deliberation is over, and I am entirely blown up.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I'll take notes of this affair.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Mighty well, Sir. So you are in love it ſeems;—and you want to be married it ſeems?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: My bleſſed aunt!—O how proud I am of the relation.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Dear Bab, give me quarter before all this company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: You are in love, you old fool, are you? and you want to marry Miſs Walſingham, indeed!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I never heard a pleaſanter ſpoken gentlewoman —O hone, if I had the taming of her, ſhe ſhou'd never be abuſive, without keeping a civil tongue in her head.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEM.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and when is the happy day to be fix'd?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What the devil, is this true, General?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: True.—Can you believe ſuch an abſurdity?

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Why, will you deny, you miſerable old mummy, that you made propoſal of marriage to her?—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Yes I do—no I don't—propoſals of marriage!

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: In favour of your ſon.—I'll help him out a little. aſide

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Yes, in favour of my ſon—what the devil ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Shall I take a leſſon from this lady, Mr. Belville? Perhaps if the women of virtue were to pluck up a little ſpirit, they might be ſoon as well treated as kept miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Harkee, General Savage, I believe you aſſert a falſehood; but if you ſpeak the truth, give your ſon this moment to Miſs Walſingham, and let me be fairly rid of my rival.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: My ſon! Miſs Walſingham!—Miſs Walſingham, my ſon!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: It will do, Horace; it will do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: No prevarications, General Savage; do what I bid you inſtantly, or by all the wrongs of an enraged woman, I'll ſo expoſe you.—

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: What a fine fellow this is, to have the command of an army!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: If Miſs Walſingham can be prevailed upon.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: O, ſhe'll oblige you readily—But you muſt ſettle a good fortune upon your ſon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: That he ſhall do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Miſs Walſingham, my Dear—

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: I can refuſe nothing either to your requeſt, or to the requeſt of the General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Oblige me with your hand then, Madam: come here you—come here Captain. There, there is Miſs Walſingham's hand for you.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And as pretty a little fiſt it is, as any in the three kingdoms.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Torrington ſhall ſettle the fortune.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I give you joy moſt heartily, Madam.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: We all give her joy.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Mine is beyond the power of expreſſion.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: (aſide to the company) And ſo is the General's, I believe.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O faith, that may be eaſily ſeen by the ſweetneſs of his countenance.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Well, the cauſe being now at laſt determin'd, I think we may all retire from the court.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And without any great credit, I fear, to the General.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: By my ſoul, you may ſay that.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Do you murmur, Sir?—Come this moment home with me.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I'll go any where to hide this miſerable head of mine: what a damn'd campaign have I made of it!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, if I was in the General's place, I'd divide the houſe with this devil; I'd keep within doors myſelf, and make her take the outſide.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The day has been a buſy one, thanks to the communicative diſpoſition of the Captain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: And the evening ſhould be chearful.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I ſhan't therefore part with one of you, 'till we have had a hearty laugh at our general adventures.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: They have been very whimſical indeed; yet if repreſented on the ſtage, I hope they wou'd be found not only entertaining, but inſtructive.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Inſtructive! why the modern Critics ſay that the only buſineſs of Comedy is to make people laugh.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: That is degrading the dignity of letters exceedingly, as well as leſſening the utility of the ſtage —A good comedy is a capital effort of genius, and ſhould therefore be directed to the nobleſt purpoſes.

sp.speaker: Miſs WAL.
sp.p: Very true; and unleſs we learn ſomething while we chuckle, the carpenter who nails a Pantomime together, will be entitled to more applauſe, than the beſt comic poet in the kingdom.
